ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-3 Total pages: 142 TS. 1 Introduction 1 The Working Group III (WG III) contribution to the IPCC’s Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) assesses 2 the current state of knowledge on the scientific, technological, environmental, economic and social 3 aspects of climate change mitigation. It builds on previous IPCC reports, including the WG III 4 contribution to the IPCC’s Fifth Assessment Report (AR5) and the three Special Reports of the Sixth 5 Assessment cycle on: Global warming of 1.5°C (SR 1.5°C); Climate Change and Land (SRCCL); and, 6 the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate (SROCC).17 The report assesses new literature, methodological and recent developments, and changes in approaches 8 towards climate change mitigation since the IPCC AR5 report was published in 2014. 9 The global science and policy landscape on climate change mitigation has evolved since AR5. The 10 development of the literature reflects, among other factors, the UN Framework Convention on Climate 11 Change (UNFCCC), the outcomes of its Kyoto Protocol and the goals of the Paris Agreement {13, 14, 12 15}, and the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development {1, 4, 17}. Literature further highlights the 13 growing role of non-state and sub-national actors in the global effort to address climate change, 14 including cities, businesses, citizens, transnational initiatives and public-private entities {5, 8, 13}. It 15 draws attention to the decreasing cost of some low emission technologies {2, 6, 12} and the evolving 16 role of international cooperation {14}, finance {15} and innovation {16}. Emerging literature examines 17 the global spread of climate policies, strengthened mitigation actions in developing countries, sustained 18 reductions in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in some developed countries and the continuing 19 challenges for mitigation. 20 There are ever closer linkages between climate change mitigation, development pathways and the 21 pursuit of sustainable development goals. Development pathways largely drive GHG emissions and 22 hence shape the mitigation challenge and the portfolio of available responses {4}. The co-benefits and 23 risks of mitigation responses also differ according to stages of development and national capabilities 24 {1, 2, 3, 4, 13}. Climate change mitigation framed in the context of sustainable development, equity, 25 and poverty eradication, and rooted in the development aspirations of the society within which they 26 take place, will be more acceptable, durable and effective. 27 This report includes new assessment approaches that go beyond those evaluated in the previous IPCC 28 WG III reports. In addition to sectoral and systems chapters {6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11}, this report includes, for 29 the first time, chapters dedicated to cross-sectoral perspectives {12} demand, services and social aspects 30 of mitigation (Box TS.11) {5} and innovation, technology development and transfer {16}. The 31 assessment of future pathways combines a forward-looking assessment of near- to medium-term 32 perspectives up to 2050, including ways of shifting development pathways towards sustainability {4}, 33 with an assessment of long-term outcome-oriented pathways up to 2100 {3}. Collaboration between 34 the IPCC Working Groups is reflected in Cross-Working Group boxes which address topics such as the 35 economic benefits from avoided impacts along mitigation pathways {Cross-Working Group Box 1 in 36 Chapter 3}, climate change and urban areas {Cross-Working Group Box 2 in Chapter 8}, mitigation 37 and adaptation through the bioeconomy {Cross-Working Group Box 3 in Chapter 12} and Solar 38 Radiation Modification . This assessment also gives 39 FOOTNOTE 1The three Special Reports are: Global Warming of 1.5°C: an IPCC Special Report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways, in the context of strengthening the global response to the threat of climate change, sustainable development, and efforts to eradicate poverty (2018); Climate Change and Land: an IPCC Special Report on climate change, desertification, land degradation, sustainable land management, food security, and greenhouse gas fluxes in terrestrial ecosystems (2019); IPCC Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate (2019). AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-4 Total pages: 142 greater attention than AR5 to social, economic and environmental dimensions of mitigation actions, 1 and institutional, legal and financial aspects . 2 The report draws from literature on broad and diverse analytic frameworks across multiple disciplines. 3 These include, inter alia: economic and environmental efficiency {1}; ethics and equity {4, 5, 17}; 4 innovation and the dynamics of socio-technical transitions {16}; and, socio-political-institutional 5 frameworks {1, 5, 13, 14, 17}. These help to identify synergies and trade-offs with sustainable 6 development goals, challenges and windows of opportunity for action including co-benefits, and 7 equitable transitions at local, national and global scales. . 8 This Technical Summary (TS) of the WG III contribution to the IPCC’s Sixth Assessment Report 9 broadly follows the report chapter order and is structured as follows. 10 • TS Section 2 sets out how the global context for mitigation has changed and summarises signs of 11 progress and continuing challenges. 12 • TS Section 3 evaluates emission trends and drivers including recent sectoral, financial, 13 technological and policy developments. 14 • TS Section 4 identifies mitigation and development pathways in the near and medium- term to 15 2050, and in the longer term to 2100. This section includes an assessment of how mitigation 16 pathways deploying different portfolios of mitigation responses are consistent with limiting global 17 warming to different levels. 18 • TS Section 5 summarises recent advances in knowledge across sectors and systems including 19 energy, urban and other settlements, transport, buildings, industry, and agriculture, forestry and 20 other land use. 21 • TS Section 6 examines how enabling conditions including behaviour and lifestyle, policy, 22 governance and institutional capacity, international cooperation, finance, and innovation and 23 technology can accelerate mitigation in the context of sustainable development 24 • TS Section 7 evaluates how mitigation can be achieved in the context of sustainable development, 25 while maximising co-benefits and minimising risks. 26 27 Throughout this Technical Summary the validity of findings, confidence in findings, and cross 28 references to Technical Summary sections, figures and tables are shown in ( ) brackets.2References to 29 the underlying report are shown in brackets. 30 31 32 FOOTNOTE 2Each finding is grounded in an evaluation of the underlying evidence, typeset in italics. The validity of a finding is evaluated in terms of the evidence quality – ‘limited’, ‘medium’, ‘robust’ – and the degree of agreement between sources – ‘low’, ‘medium’, ‘high’. A level of confidence is expressed using five qualifiers: very low, low, medium, high and very high. Generally, the level of confidence is highest where there is robust evidence from multiple sources and high agreement. For findings with, for example, ‘robust evidence, medium agreement’, a confidence statement may not always be appropriate. The assessed likelihood of an outcome or a result is described as: virtually certain 99–100% probability, very likely 90–100%, likely 66–100%, about as likely as not 33–66%, unlikely 0–33%, very unlikely 0–10%, exceptionally unlikely 0–1%. Additional terms may also be used when appropriate, consistent with the IPCC uncertainty guidance: https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/05/uncertainty-guidance-note.pdf. AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-5 Total pages: 142 TS. 2 The changed global context, signs of progress and continuing 1 challenges 2 Since the IPCC’s Fifth Assessment Report (AR5), important changes that have emerged include 3 the specific objectives established in the Paris Agreement of 2015 (for temperature, adaptation 4 and finance), rising climate impacts, and higher levels of societal awareness and support for 5 climate action (high confidence
    ). Meeting the long-term temperature goal in the Paris Agreement, 6 however, implies a rapid inflection in GHG emission trends and accelerating decline towards ‘net zero’. 7 This is implausible without urgent and ambitious action at all scales. 9 Effective and equitable climate policies are largely compatible with the broader goal of 10 sustainable development and efforts to eradicate poverty as enshrined in the UN 2030 Agenda for 11 Sustainable Development and its 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), notwithstanding 12 trade-offs in some cases (high confidence
    ). Taking urgent action to combat climate change and its 13 impacts is one of the 17 SDGs (SDG13). However, climate change mitigation also has synergies and/or 14 trade-offs with many other SDGs. There has been a strong relationship between development and GHG 15 emissions, as historically both per capita and absolute emissions have risen with industrialisation. 16 However, recent evidence shows countries can grow their economies while reducing emissions. 17 Countries have different priorities in achieving the SDGs and reducing emissions as informed by their 18 respective national conditions and capabilities. Given the differences in GHG emissions contributions, 19 degree of vulnerability and impacts, as well as capacities within and between nations, equity and justice 20 are important considerations for effective climate policy and for securing national and international 21 support for deep decarbonisation. Achieving sustainable development and eradicating poverty would 22 involve effective and equitable climate policies at all levels from local to global scale. Failure to address 23 questions of equity and justice over time can undermine social cohesion and stability. International co-24 operation can enhance efforts to achieve ambitious global climate mitigation in the context of 25 sustainable development pathways towards fulfilling the SDGs are illustrated in Figure TS.1. 27 28 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-6 Total pages: 142 1 2 Figure TS.1: Sustainable development pathways towards fulfilling the Sustainable Development Goals 3 Figure TS.1 legend: The graph shows how global average per capita GHG emissions (vertical axis) and relative 4 "Historic Index of Human Development" (HIHD) levels (horizonal axis) have increased globally since the 5 industrial revolution (grey line). The emphasis of pathways into the sustainable development zone differ (green arrows) 13 but in each case transformations are needed in how human development is attained while limiting GHG 14 emissions. 15 16 The transition to a low carbon economy depends on a wide range of closely intertwined drivers 17 and constraints, including policies and technologies where notable advances over the past decade 18 have opened up new and large-scale opportunities for deep decarbonisation, and for alternative 19 development pathways which could deliver multiple social and developmental goals (high 20 confidence). Drivers for-, and constraints on-, low carbon societal transitions comprise economic and 21 technological factors (the means by which services such as food, heating and shelter are provided and 22 for whom, the emissions intensity of traded products, finance and investment), socio-political issues 23 (political economy, equity and fairness, social innovation and behaviour change), and institutional 24 factors (legal framework and institutions, and the quality of international cooperation). In addition to 25 being deeply intertwined, all the factors matter to varying degrees, depending on prevailing social, 26 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-7 Total pages: 142 economic, cultural and political context. They often both drive and inhibit transitions at the same time, 1 within and across different scales. The development and deployment of innovative technologies and 2 systems at scale are important for achieving deep decarbonisation, and in recent years, the cost of 3 several low carbon technologies has declined sharply as deployment has risen rapidly. (Figure TS.7) 4 5 Accelerating mitigation to prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system 6 will require the integration of broadened assessment frameworks and tools that combine multiple 7 perspectives, applied in a context of multi-level governance (high confidence
    ). Analysing a 8 challenge on the scale of fully decarbonising our economies entails integration of multiple analytic 9 frameworks. Approaches to risk assessment and resilience, established across IPCC Working Groups, 10 are complemented by frameworks for probing the challenges in implementing mitigation. Aggregate 11 frameworks include cost-effectiveness analysis towards given objectives, and cost-benefit analysis, 12 both of which have been developing to take fuller account of advances in understanding risks and 13 innovation, the dynamics of sectors and systems and of climate impacts, and welfare economic theory 14 including growing consensus on long-term discounting. Ethical frameworks consider the fairness of 15 processes and outcomes which can help ameliorate distributional impacts across income groups, 16 countries and generations. Transition and transformation frameworks explain and evaluate the 17 dynamics of transitions to low-carbon systems arising from interactions amongst levels. Psychological, 18 behavioural and political frameworks outline the constraints (and opportunities) arising from human 19 psychology and the power of incumbent interests. A comprehensive understanding of climate mitigation 20 must combine these multiple frameworks. Together with established risk frameworks, these collectively 21 help to explain potential synergies and trade-offs in mitigation, implying a need for a wide portfolio of 22 policies attuned to different actors and levels of decision-making, and underpin ‘just transition’ 23 strategies in diverse contexts. 24 The speed, direction, and depth of any transition will be determined by choices in the 25 environmental, technological, economic, socio-cultural and institutional realms (high confidence
    ). 26 Transitions in specific systems can be gradual or can be rapid and disruptive. The pace of a transition 27 can be impeded by ‘lock-in’ generated by existing physical capital, institutions, and social norms. The 28 interaction between politics, economics and power relationships is central to explaining why broad 29 commitments do not always translate to urgent action. At the same time, attention to, and support for, 30 climate policies and low carbon societal transitions has generally increased, as the impacts have become 31 more salient. Both public and private financing and financial structures strongly affect the scale and 32 balance of high and low carbon investments. Societal and behavioural norms, regulations and 33 institutions are essential conditions to accelerate low carbon transitions in multiple sectors, whilst 34 addressing distributional concerns endemic to any major transition. The COVID-19 pandemic has also 35 had far-reaching impacts on the global economic and social system, and recovery will present both 36 challenges and opportunities for climate mitigation. (Box TS.1) 38 Achieving the global transition to a low-carbon, climate-resilient and sustainable world requires 39 purposeful and increasingly coordinated planning and decisions at many scales of governance 40 including local, subnational, national and global levels (high confidence
    ). Accelerating mitigation 41 globally would imply strengthening policies adopted to date, expanding the effort across options, 42 sectors, and countries, and broadening responses to include more diverse actors and societal processes 43 at multiple – including international – levels. The effective governance of climate change entails strong 44 action across multiple jurisdictions and decision-making levels, including regular evaluation and 45 learning. Choices that cause climate change as well as the processes for making and implementing 46 relevant decisions involve a range of non-nation state actors such as cities, businesses, and civil society 47 organisations. At global, national and subnational levels, climate change actions are interwoven with, 48 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-8 Total pages: 142 and embedded in, the context of much broader social, economic and political goals. Therefore, the 1 governance required to address climate change has to navigate power, political, economic, and social 2 dynamics at all levels of decision making. Effective climate-governing institutions, and openness to 3 experimentation on a variety of institutional arrangements, policies and programmes can play a vital 4 role in engaging stakeholders and building momentum for effective climate action. 6 GHG emissions continued to rise to 2019, although the growth of global GHG emissions has 7 slowed over the past decade (high confidence
    . Delivering the updated Nationally Determined 8 Contributions (NDCs) to 2030 would turn this into decline, but the implied global emissions by 2030, 9 still exceed pathways consistent with 1.5°C by a large margin and are near the upper end of the range 10 of modelled pathways that likely limit warming to 2°C or below. In all chapters of this report there is 11 evidence of progress towards deeper mitigation, but there remain many obstacles to be overcome. (TS.3) GHG emissions have continued to grow at high absolute rates. Emissions increased by 8.9 GtCO2eq from 2000-2009 and by 6.5 GtCO2eq 2010-2019, reaching 59 GtCO2eq in 2019. (TS.3) At least 24 countries have reduced both territorial carbon dioxide (CO2) and GHG emissions and consumption-based CO2emissions in absolute terms for at least 10 years, including consumption-based CO2emissions. Of these, six are Western and Northern European countries that started reducing in the 1970s, six are former Eastern Bloc countries with consistent reductions since the 1990s, and 12 more have reduced since the mid-2000s. Some have done so at rapid sustained CO2reduction rates of 4% per year. (TS.3) The combined emissions reductions of these 24 countries were outweighed by rapid emissions growth elsewhere, particularly among developing countries that have grown from a much lower base of per capita emissions. Uncertainties in emissions levels and changes over time prevents a precise assessment of reductions in some cases. The per capita emissions of developed countries remain high, particularly in Australia, Canada, and the United States. Lockdown policies in response to COVID-19 led to an estimated global drop of 5.8% in CO2emissions in 2020 relative to 2019. Energy demand reduction occurred across sectors, except in residential buildings due to teleworking and homeschooling. The transport sector was particularly impacted and international aviation emissions declined by 45%. (Box TS.1) Atmospheric CO2concentrations continued to rise in 2020 and emissions have already rebounded as lockdown policies are eased. Economic recovery packages currently include support for fossil fuel industries. (Box TS.1; Box TS.8) Sectors Multiple low-carbon electricity generation and storage technologies have made rapid progress: costs have reduced, deployment has scaled up, and performance has improved. These include solar photovoltaics (PV), onshore and offshore wind, and batteries. In many contexts solar PV and onshore wind power are now competitive with fossil-based generation. (TS.3) Although deployment is increasing rapidly, low-carbon electricity generation deployment levels and rates are currently insufficient to meet stringent climate goals. The combined market share of solar PV and wind generation technologies are still below 10%. Global low-carbon electricity generation will have to reach 100% by 2050, which is challenged by the continuous global increase in electricity demand. The contribution of biomass has absolute limits. (TS.5, 2.5) The rate of emissions growth from coal slowed since 2010 as coal power plants were retired in the United States and Europe, fewer new plants were added in China, Global coal emissions may not have peaked yet, and a few countries and international development banks continue to fund and develop new coal capacity, AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-10 Total pages: 142 Signs of progress Continuing challenges and a large number of planned global plants were scrapped or converted to co-firing with biomass. (TS.3) {2.7, 6.3} especially abroad. The lifetime emissions of current fossil-based energy infrastructures may already exceed the remaining carbon budget for keeping warming below 1.5°C. (TS.3) Deforestation has declined since 2010 and net forest cover increased. Government initiatives and international moratoria were successful in reducing deforestation in the Amazon between 2004 and 2015, while regrowth and regeneration occurred in Europe, Eurasia and North America. (TS.5.6.1) The long-term maintenance of low deforestation rates is challenging. Deforestation in the Amazon has risen again over the past four years. Other parts of the world also face steady, or rapidly increasing, deforestation. {7.3.1} Electrification of public transport services is demonstrated as a feasible, scalable and affordable mitigation option to decarbonise mass transportation. Electric vehicles (e-vehicles) are the fastest growing segment of the automobile industry, having achieved double-digit market share by 2020 in many countries. When charged with low-carbon electricity, these vehicles can significantly reduce emissions. Transport emissions have remained roughly constant, growing at an average of 2% per annum between 2010-2019 due to the persistence of high travel demand, heavier vehicles, low efficiencies, and car-centric development. The full decarbonisation of e-vehicles requires that they are charged with zero-carbon electricity, and that car production, shipping, aviation and supply chains are decarbonized. (TS.3) There has been a significant global transition from coal and biomass use in buildings towards modern energy carriers and efficient conversion technologies. This led to efficiency improvements and some emissions reductions in developed countries, as well as significant gains in health and well-being outcomes in developing regions. Nearly Zero Energy (NZE) Buildings or low-energy Buildings are achievable in all regions and climate zones for both new and existing buildings. There is a significant lock-in risk in all regions given the long lifespans of buildings and the low ambition of building policies. This is the case for both existing buildings in developed countries, and also for new buildings in developing countries that are also challenged by the lack of technical capacity and effective governance. Emissions reductions in developed countries have been outweighed by the increase in population growth, floor area per capita and the demand for electricity and heat. The decarbonisation of most industrial processes has been demonstrated using technologies that include electricity and hydrogen for energy and feedstocks, carbon capture and utilisation technologies, and innovation in circular material flows. (TS.5.5) Industry emissions continue to increase, driven by a strong global demand for basic materials. Without reductions in material demand growth and a very rapid scale-up of low-carbon innovations, the long lifetimes of industrial capital stock risks locking-in emissions for decades to come. (TS.5.5) Policies and investment AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-11 Total pages: 142 Signs of progress Continuing challenges The Paris Agreement established a new global policy architecture to meet stringent climate goals, while avoiding many areas of deadlock that had arisen in trying to extend the Kyoto Protocol. (TS 6.3) Current national pledges under the Paris Agreement3are insufficient to limit warming to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot, and would require an abrupt acceleration of mitigation efforts after 2030 to likely limit warming to 2°C. (TS 6.3) Most wealthy countries, and a growing list of developing countries, have signaled an intention to achieve net zero GHG (or net zero CO2) emissions by mid-century. National economy-wide GHG emissions targets covered 90% of global emissions in 2020 compared to 49% in 2010. Direct and indirect climate legislation has also steadily increased and this is supported by a growing list of financial investors. (TS.6.2) Many net zero targets are ambiguously defined, and the policies needed to achieve them are not yet in place. Opposition from status quo interests, as well as insufficient low-carbon financial flows, act as barriers to establishing and implementing stringent climate policies covering all sectors. (Box TS.6) The global coverage of mandatory policies – pricing and regulation – has increased, and sectoral coverage of mitigation policies has expanded. Emission trading and carbon taxes now cover over 20% of global CO2emissions (TS 6). Allowance prices as of April 1, 2021 ranged from just over USD1 to USD50, covering between 9 and 80% of a jurisdiction’s emissions . Many countries have introduced sectoral regulations that block new investment in fossil fuel technologies. There is incomplete global policy coverage of non-CO2gases, CO2from industrial processes, and emissions outside the energy sector. Few of the world’s carbon prices are at a level consistent with various estimates of the carbon price needed to limit warming to 2°C or 1.5°C There has been a marked increase in civic and private engagement with climate governance. This includes business measures to limit emissions, invest in reforestation and develop carbon-neutral value chains such as using wood for construction. There is an upsurge in climate activism, and growing engagement of groups such as labour unions . The media coverage of climate change has also grown steadily across platforms and has generally become more accurate over time. (TS 6.2) There is no conclusive evidence that an increase in engagement results in overall pro-mitigation outcomes. A broad group of actors influence how climate governance develop over time, including a range of civic organisations, encompassing both pro-and anti-climate action groups. Accurate transference of the climate science has been undermined significantly by climate change counter-movements, in both legacy and new/social media environments through misinformation. GHG emission metrics 18 provide simplified information about the effect that emissions of different gases have on global 19 temperature or other aspects of climate, usually expressed relative to the effect of emitting CO2ǂ. This 20 information can support choices about priorities, trade-offs and synergies in mitigation policies and 21 emission targets for non-CO2 gases relative to CO2 as well as baskets of gases expressed in CO2-eq. 22 The choice of metric can affect the timing and emphasis placed on reducing emissions of Short-Lived 23 Climate Forcers (SLCFs) relative to CO2 within multi-gas abatement strategies as well as the costs of 24 such strategies. Different metric choices can also alter the time at which net zero GHG emissions are 25 calculated to be reached for any given emissions scenario. A wide range of GHG emission metrics has 26 been published in the scientific literature, which differ in terms of: (i) the key measure of climate change 27 they consider, (ii) whether they consider climate outcomes for a specified point in time or integrated 28 over a specified time horizon, (iii) the time horizon over which the metric is applied, (iv) whether they 29 apply to a single emission pulse, to emissions sustained over a period of time, or to a combination of 30 both, and (v) whether they consider the climate effect from an emission compared to the absence of that 31 emission, or compared to a reference emissions level or climate state . 32 Parties to the Paris Agreement decided to report aggregated emissions and removals (expressed as CO2-33 eq) based on the Global Warming Potential with a time horizon of 100 years (GWP100) using values 34 from IPCC AR5 or from a subsequent IPCC report as agreed upon by the CMA†, and to account for 35 future nationally determined contributions (NDCs) in accordance with this approach. Parties may also 36 report supplemental information on aggregate emissions and removals, expressed as CO2-eq, using 37 other GHG emission metrics assessed by the IPCC. 38 The WG III contribution to AR6 uses updated GWP100 values from AR6 WG I to report aggregate 39 emissions and removals unless stated otherwise. These reflect updated scientific understanding of the 40 response of the climate system to emissions of different gases and include a methodological update to 41 incorporate climate-carbon cycle feedbacks associated with the emission of non-CO2 gases (see Annex 42 II Part II Section 8 for a list of GWP100 metric values). The choice of GWP100 was made inter alia for 43 consistency with decisions under the Rulebook for the Paris Agreement and because it is the dominant 44 metric used in the literature assessed by WG III. Furthermore, for mitigation pathways that likely limit 45 global warming to 2°C or lower, using GWP100 to inform cost-effective abatement choices between 46 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-20 Total pages: 142 gases would achieve such long-term temperature goals at close to least global cost within a few percent 1 (high confidence
    ). 2 However, GWP100 is not well suited to estimate the cumulative effect on climate from sustained SLCF 3 emissions and the resulting warming at specific points in time. This is because the warming caused by 4 an individual SLCF emission pulse is not permanent, and hence, unlike CO2, the warming from 5 successive SLCF emission pulses over multiple decades or centuries depends mostly on their ongoing 6 rate of emissions rather than cumulative emissions. Recently developed step/pulse metrics such as the 7 CGTP (Combined Global Temperature Change Potential) and GWP* (referred to as GWP-star and 8 indicated by asterisk) recognise that a sustained increase/decrease in the rate of SLCF emissions has 9 indeed a similar effect on global surface temperature as one-off emission/removal of CO2. These metrics 10 use this relationship to calculate the CO2 emissions or removals that would result in roughly the same 11 temperature change as a sustained change in the rate of SLCF emissions (CGTP) over a given time 12 period, or as a varying time series of CH4 emissions (GWP*). From a mitigation perspective, this makes 13 these metrics well suited in principle to estimate the effect on the remaining carbon budget from more, 14 or less, ambitious SLCF mitigation over multiple decades compared to a given reference scenario (high 15 confidence). However, potential application in wider climate policy (e.g., to inform equitable and 16 ambitious emission targets or to support sector-specific mitigation policies) is contested and relevant 17 literature still limited. 18 All metrics have limitations and uncertainties, given that they simplify the complexity of the physical 19 climate system and its response to past and future GHG emissions. For this reason, the WG III 20 contribution to the AR6 reports emissions and mitigation options for individual gases where possible; 21 CO2-equivalent emissions are reported in addition to individual gas emissions where this is judged to 22 be policy-relevant. This approach aims to reduce the ambiguity regarding actual climate outcomes over 23 time arising from the use of any specific GHG emission metric. 25 ǂ Emission metrics also exist for aerosols, but these are not commonly used in climate policy. This assessment 26 focuses on GHG emission metrics only. 27 †The CMA is the Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Paris Agreement. See 28 18/CMA.1 (Annex, para 37) and 4/CMA.1 (Annex II, para 1) regarding the use of GHG emission metrics in 29 reporting of emissions and removals and accounting for Parties’ NDCs. 30 END BOX TS.2 HERE 31 32 Consumption-based CO2 emissions in developed countries and the Asia and Developing Pacific 33 region are higher than in other regions (high confidence

Emissions reductions are based on harmonised model emissions used for the climate assessment. 9 (Section 3.5) 10 11 There is a need to explore how accelerated mitigation – relative to NDCs and current policies – 12 could close both emission gaps, and implementation gaps. There is increasing understanding of the 13 technical content of accelerated mitigation pathways, differentiated by national circumstances, with 14 considerable, though uneven, literature at country-level (medium evidence, high agreement). 15 Transformative technological and institutional changes for the near-term include demand reductions 16 through efficiency and reduced activity, rapid decarbonisation of the electricity sector and low-carbon 17 electrification of buildings, industry and transport (robust evidence, medium agreement). A focus on 18 energy use and supply is essential, but not sufficient on its own – the land sector and food systems 19 deserve attention. The literature does not adequately include demand-side options and systems analysis, 20 and captures the impact from non-CO2 GHGs with medium confidence
    . 21 If obstacles to accelerated mitigation are rooted in underlying structural features of society, then 22 transforming such structures can support emission reductions . Countries and regions will 23 have different starting points for transition pathways. Some critical differences between countries 24 include climate conditions resulting in different heating and cooling needs, endowments with different 25 energy resources, patterns of spatial development, and political and economic conditions . The 26 way countries develop determines their capacity to accelerate mitigation and achieve other sustainable 27 development objectives simultaneously (medium confidence
    . Yet meeting ambitious 28 mitigation and development goals cannot be achieved through incremental change (robust evidence, 29 medium agreement). Though development pathways result from the actions of a wide range of actors, 30 it is possible to shift development pathways through policies and enhancing enabling conditions (limited 31 evidence, medium agreement). 32 Shifting development pathways towards sustainability offers ways to broaden the range of levers 33 and enablers that a society can use to accelerate mitigation and increases the likelihood of making 34 progress simultaneously on climate action and other development goals (Box TS.3) {Cross-35 Chapter Box 5 in Chapter 4, Figure 4.7, 4.3}. There are practical options to shift development 36 pathways in ways that advance mitigation and other sustainable development objectives, supporting 37 political feasibility, increase resources to meet multiple goals, and reduce emissions (limited evidence, 38 high agreement). Concrete examples, assessed in chapter 4 of this report, include high employment and 39 low emissions structural change, fiscal reforms for mitigation and social contract, combining housing 40 policies to deliver both housing and transport mitigation, and change economic, social and spatial 41 patterns of development of the agriculture sector provide the basis for sustained reductions in emissions 42 from deforestation. 43 44 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-33 Total pages: 142 START BOX TS.3 HERE 1 Box TS.3: Shifting development pathways to increase sustainability and broaden mitigation 2 options 3 In this report, development pathways refer to the patterns of development resulting from multiple 4 decisions and choices made by many actors in the national and global contexts. Each society whether 5 in developing or developed regions follows its own pattern of growth (Figure TS.13). Development 6 pathways can also be described at smaller scales (e.g., for regions or cities) and for sectoral systems. 7 Development pathways are major drivers of GHG emissions . There is compelling evidence to 8 show that continuing along existing development pathways will not achieve rapid and deep emission 9 reductions. In the absence of shifts in development pathways, conventional mitigation policy 10 instruments may not be able to limit global emissions to a degree sufficient to meet ambitious mitigation 11 goals or they may only be able to do so at very high economic and social costs. 12 Policies to shift development pathways, on the other hand, make mitigation policies more effective. 13 Shifting development pathways broadens the scope for synergies between sustainable development 14 objectives and mitigation. Development pathways also determine the enablers and levers available for 15 adaptation and for achieving other SDGs. 16 There are many instances in which reducing GHG emissions and moving towards the achievement of 17 other development objectives can go hand in hand . Integrated 18 policies can support the creation of synergies between action to combat climate change and its impacts 19 (SDG 13) and other SDGs. For example, when measures promoting walkable urban areas are combined 20 with electrification and clean renewable energy, there are several co-benefits to be attained. These 21 include reduced pressures on agricultural land from reduced urban growth, health co-benefits from 22 cleaner air and benefits from enhanced mobility {8.2, 8.4, 4.4.1}. Energy efficiency in buildings and 23 energy poverty alleviation through improved access to clean fuels also deliver significant health 24 benefits. 25 However, decisions about mitigation actions, and their timing and scale, may entail trade-offs with the 26 achievement of other national development objectives in the near-, mid- and long-term {Chapter 12}. 27 In the near-term, for example, regulations may ban vehicles from city centres to reduce congestion and 28 local air pollution but reduce mobility and choice. Increasing green spaces within cities without caps 29 on housing prices may involve trade-offs with affordable housing and push low-income residents 30 outside the city {8.2.2}. In the mid- and long-term, large-scale deployment of biomass energy raises 31 concerns about food security and biodiversity conservation . 32 Prioritising is one way to manage these trade-offs, addressing some national development objectives 33 earlier than others. Another way is to adopt policy packages aimed at shifting development pathways 34 towards sustainability (SDPS) as they expand the range of tools available to simultaneously achieve 35 multiple development objectives and accelerate mitigation. (Box TS.3 Figure 1) 36 What does shifting development pathways towards sustainability entail? 37 Shifting development pathways towards sustainability implies making transformative changes that 38 disrupt existing developmental trends. Such choices would not be marginal, but include technological, 39 systemic and socio-behavioural changes {4.4}. Decision points also arise with new infrastructure, 40 sustainable supply chains, institutional capacities for evidence-based and integrated decision-making, 41 financial alignment towards low-carbon socially responsible investments, just transitions and shifts in 42 behaviour and norms to support shifts away from fossil fuel consumption. Adopting multi-level 43 governance modes, tackling corruption where it inhibits shifts to sustainability, and improving social 44 and political trust are also key for aligning and supporting long-term environmentally just policies and 45 processes. 46 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-34 Total pages: 142 How to shift development pathways? 1 Shifting development paths is complex. Changes that involve ‘dissimilar, unfamiliar and more complex 2 science-based components’ take more time, acceptance and legitimation and involve complex social 3 learning, even when they promise large gains. Despite the complexities of the interactions that result in 4 patterns of development, history also shows that societies can influence the direction of development 5 pathways based on choices made by decision-makers, citizens, the private sector, and social 6 stakeholders. Shifts in development pathways result from both sustained political interventions and 7 bottom-up changes in public opinion. Collective action by individuals as part of social movements or 8 lifestyle changes underpins system change. . 9 Sectoral transitions that aim to shift development pathways often have multiple objectives and deploy 10 a diverse mix of policies and institutional measures. Context specific governance conditions can 11 significantly enable or disable sectoral transitions . 12 The necessary transformational changes are anticipated to be more acceptable if rooted in the 13 development aspirations of the economy and society within which they take place and may enable a 14 new social contract to address a complex set of inter-linkages across sectors, classes, and the whole 15 economy. Taking advantage of windows of opportunity and disruptions to mindsets and socio-technical 16 systems could advance deeper transformations. 17 How can shifts in development pathways be implemented by actors in different contexts? 18 Shifting development pathways to increased sustainability is a shared aspiration. Yet since countries 19 differ in starting points (e.g., social, economic, cultural, political) and historical backgrounds, they have 20 different urgent needs in terms of facilitating the economic, social, and environmental dimensions of 21 sustainable development and, therefore, give different priorities . The appropriate set of 22 policies to shift development pathways thus depends on national circumstances and capacities. 23 Shifting development pathways towards sustainability needs to be supported by multilateral 24 partnerships to strengthen suitable capacity, technological innovation (TS 6.5), and financial flows (TS. 25 6.4). The international community can play a particularly key role by helping ensure the necessary broad 26 participation in climate-mitigation efforts, including by countries at different development levels, 27 through sustained support for policies and partnerships that support shifting development pathways 28 towards sustainability while promoting equity and being mindful of different transition capacities. 29 30 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-35 Total pages: 142 1 Box TS.3 Figure 1 Shifting development pathways to increased sustainability: Choices by a wide range of 2 actors at key decision points on development pathways can reduce barriers and provide more tools to 3 accelerate mitigation and achieve other Sustainable Development Goals. 4 END BOX TS.3 HERE 5 6 Policies can shift development pathways. There are examples of policies implemented in the 7 pursuit of overall societal development objectives, such as job creation, macro-economic stability, 8 economic growth, and public health and welfare. In some countries, such policies are framed as part 9 of a just transition (Box TS.3), however, they can have major influence on mitigative capacity, and 10 hence can be seen as tools to broaden mitigation options (medium confidence
    {4.3.3}. Coordinated 11 policy mixes would need to orchestrate multiple actors – individuals, groups and collectives, corporate 12 actors, institutions and infrastructure actors – to deepen decarbonisation and shift pathways towards 13 sustainability. Shifts in one country may spill over to other countries. Shifting development pathways 14 can jointly support mitigation and adaptation {4.4.2}. Some studies explore the risks of high complexity 15 and potential delay attached to shifting development pathways. (Box TS.4, Figure TS.11) 16 An increasing number of mitigation strategies up to 2050 (mid-term) have been developed by 17 various actors. A growing number of such strategies aim at net zero GHG or CO2 emissions, but 18 it is not yet possible to draw global implications due to the limited size of sample (medium 19 evidence; low agreement) . Non-state actors are also engaging in a wide range of mitigation 20 initiatives. When adding up emission reduction potentials, sub-national and non-state international 21 cooperative initiatives could reduce emissions by up to about 20 GtCO2-eq in 2030 (limited evidence, 22 medium agreement) . Yet perceived or real conflicts between mitigation and other SDGs can 23 impede such action. If undertaken without precaution, accelerated mitigation is found to have 24 significant implications for development objectives and macroeconomic costs at country level. The 25 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-36 Total pages: 142 literature shows that employment effect of mitigation policies tends to be limited on aggregate but can 1 be significant at sectoral level (limited evidence, medium agreement). Detailed design of mitigation 2 policies is critical for distributional impacts and avoiding lock-in (high confidence
    ), though further 3 research is needed in that direction. 4 The literature identifies a broad set of enabling conditions that can both foster shifting 5 development pathways and accelerated mitigation (medium evidence, high agreement). Policy 6 integration is a necessary component of shifting development pathways, addressing multiple objectives. 7 To this aim, mobilising a range of policies is preferable to single policy instruments (high confidence
    ). 8 . Governance for climate mitigation and shifting development pathways is enhanced when 9 tailored to national and local contexts. Improved institutions and effective governance enable ambitious 10 action on climate and can help bridge implementation gaps (medium evidence, high agreement). Given 11 that strengthening institutions may be a long-term endeavour, it needs attention in the near-term . 12 Accelerated mitigation and shifting development pathways necessitates both re-directing existing 13 financial flows from high- to low-emissions technologies and systems and to provide additional 14 resources to overcome current financial barriers (high confidence
    ) {4.4.1}. Opportunities exist in the 15 near-term to close the finance gap . At the national level, public finance for actions promoting 16 sustainable development helps broaden the scope of mitigation (medium confidence
    . Changes in 17 behaviour and lifestyles are important to move beyond mitigation as incremental change, and when 18 supporting shifts to more sustainable development pathways will broaden the scope of mitigation 19 (medium confidence
    . 20 Some enabling conditions can be put in place relatively quickly while some others may take time 21 to establish underscoring the importance of early action (high confidence
    ). Depending on context, 22 some enabling conditions such as such as promoting innovation may take time to establish. Other 23 enabling conditions, such as improved access to financing, can be put in place in a relatively short time 24 frame, and can yield rapid results {4.4, Figure 5.14, 13.9, 14.5, 15.6, 16.3, 16.4, 16.5, Cross-Chapter 25 Box 12 in Chapter 16}. Focusing on development pathways and considering how to shift them may also 26 yield rapid results by providing tools to accelerate mitigation and achieve other sustainable development 27 goals. . Charting just transitions to net zero may provide a vision, which policy measures can 28 help achieve (Box TS.4, Box TS.8). 29 Equity can be an important enabler, increasing the level of ambition for accelerated mitigation 30 (high confidence
    ) . Equity deals with the distribution of costs and benefits and how these are 31 shared, as per social contracts, national policy and international agreements. Transition pathways have 32 distributional consequences such as large changes in employment and economic structure (high 33 confidence). The just transition concept has become an international focal point tying together social 34 movements, trade unions, and other key stakeholders to ensure equity is better accounted for in low-35 carbon transitions (Box TS.4). The effectiveness of cooperative action and the perception of fairness of 36 such arrangements are closely related in that pathways that prioritise equity and allow broad stakeholder 37 participation can enable broader consensus for the transformational change implicit in the need for 38 deeper mitigation (robust evidence, medium agreement). (Box TS.4) 39 40 START BOX TS.4 HERE 41 Box TS. 4: Just Transition 42 The Just Transition framework refers to a set of principles, processes and practices aimed at ensuring 43 that no people, workers, places, sectors, countries or regions are left behind in the move from a high-44 carbon to a low-carbon economy. It includes respect and dignity for vulnerable groups; creation of 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-37 Total pages: 142 decent jobs; social protection; employment rights; fairness in energy access and use and social dialogue 1 and democratic consultation with relevant stakeholders. 2 The concept has evolved, becoming prominent in the United States in 1980, related to environmental 3 regulations that resulted in job losses from highly polluting industries. Traced from a purely labour 4 movement, trade union space, the Just Transition framework emphasises that decent work and 5 environmental protection are not incompatible. During COP 24, with the Just Transition Silesia 6 Declaration, the concept gained in recognition and was signed by 56 Heads of State. 7 Implicit in a Just Transition is the notion of well-being, equity and justice – the realisation that 8 transitions are inherently disruptive and deliberate effort may be required to ensure communities 9 dependent on fossil-fuel based economies and industries do not suffer disproportionately {Chapter 4}. 10 ‘Just transitions’ are integral to the European Union as mentioned in the EU Green Deal, the Scottish 11 Government’s development plans and other national low carbon transition strategies. The US Green 12 New Deal Resolution puts structural inequality, poverty mitigation, and ‘Just Transitions’ at its centre. 13 There is a growing awareness of the need for shifting finance towards Just Transition in the context of 14 the COVID-19, in particular, public finance and governance have a major role in allowing Just 15 Transition broadly . 16 In the immediate aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, low oil prices created additional financial 17 problems for fossil fuel producer countries faced with loss of revenue and reduced fiscal latitude and 18 space. Public spending and social safety nets associated with the proceeds from producer economies 19 can be affected as assets become stranded and spending on strategic sustainable development goals such 20 as free education and health care services are neglected. Fiscal challenges are intricately linked to ‘Just 21 Transitions’ and the management associated with sustainable energy transition. There is no certainty on 22 how energy systems will recover post-COVID-19. However, ‘Just Transitions’ will have equity 23 implications if stimulus packages are implemented without due regard for the differentiated scales and 24 speeds and national and regional contexts, especially in the context of developing countries. 25 A Just Transition entails targeted and proactive measures from governments, agencies, and other non-26 state authorities to ensure that any negative social, environmental, or economic impacts of economy-27 wide transitions are minimised, whilst benefits are maximised for those disproportionally affected. 28 These proactive measures include eradication of poverty, regulating prosperity and creating jobs in 29 “green” sectors. In addition, governments, polluting industries, corporations, and those more able to 30 pay higher associated taxes, can pay for transition costs by providing a welfare safety net and adequate 31 compensation to people, communities, and regions that have been impacted by pollution, or are 32 marginalised, or are negatively impacted by a transition from a high- to low- carbon economy and 33 society. There is, nonetheless, increased recognition that resources that can enable the transition, 34 international development institutions, as well as other transitional drivers such as tools, strategies and 35 finance, are scarce. A sample of global efforts are summarised in Box TS.4 Figure 1. 36 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-38 Total pages: 142 1 Box TS.4 Figure 1: Just Transitions around the world, 2020: Panel A shows commissions, task forces, 2 dialogues behind a Just Transition in many countries; Panel B shows the funds related to the Just 3 Transition within the European Union Green Deal, and Panel C shows the European Union’s Platform 4 for Coal Regions in Transition. 5 END BOX TS.4 HERE 6 7 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-39 Total pages: 142 TS. 4.2 Long-term mitigation pathways 1 The characteristics of a wide range of long-term mitigation pathways, their common elements 2 and differences are assessed in Chapter 3.     More than 2000 quantitative emissions 5 pathways were submitted to the AR6 scenarios database, of which more than 1200 pathways included 6 sufficient information for the associated warming to be assessed (consistent with AR6 WG I methods). 7 (Box TS.5) 8 Many pathways in the literature show how to likely limit global warming to 2°C with no overshoot 9 or to limit warming to 1.5°C with limited overshoot compared to 1850-1900. The likelihood of 10 limiting warming to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot has dropped in AR6 WG III compared 11 to AR6 SR1.5 because global GHG emissions have risen since 2017, leading to higher near-term 12 emissions (2030) and higher cumulative CO2 emissions until the time of net zero (medium 13 confidence). Only a small number of published pathways limit global warming to 1.5°C without 14 overshoot over the course of the 21stcentury. 15 Mitigation pathways limiting warming to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot reach 50% CO2 16 reductions in the 2030s, relative to 2019, then reduce emissions further to reach net zero CO2 17 emissions in the 2050s. Pathways likely limiting warming to 2°C reach 50% reductions in the 18 2040s and net zero CO2 by 2070s (medium confidence
    ). (Figure TS.10, Box TS.6) 19 Cost-effective mitigation pathways assuming immediate action to likely limit warming to 2°C are 20 associated with net global GHG emissions of 30-49 GtCO2-eq yr-1by 2030 and 13-26 GtCO2-eq 21 yr-1by 2050 (medium confidence
    . This corresponds to reductions, relative to 2019 levels, of 13-45% 22 by 2030 and 52-76% by 2050. Pathways that limit global warming to below 1.5°C with no or limited 23 overshoot require a further acceleration in the pace of transformation, with net GHG emissions typically 24 around 21-36 GtCO2-eq yr-1by 2030 and 1-15 GtCO2-eq yr-1by 2050; this corresponds to reductions of 25 34–60% by 2030 and 73-98% by 2050 relative to 2019 levels. 26 27 START BOX TS.5 HERE 28 Box TS.5: Illustrative Mitigation Pathways (IMPs), and Shared Socio-economic Pathways 29 (SSPs) 30 The Illustrative Mitigation Pathways (IMPs) 31 The over 2500 model-based pathways submitted to the AR6 scenarios database pathways explore 32 different possible evolutions of future energy and land use (with and without climate policy) and the 33 consequences for greenhouse gas emissions. 34 From the full range of pathways, five archetype scenarios – referred to in this report as Illustrative 35 Mitigation Pathways (IMPs) – were selected to illustrate key mitigation-strategy themes that flow 36 through several chapters in this report. A further two pathways illustrative of high emissions assuming 37 continuation of current policies or moderately increased action were selected to show the consequences 38 of current policies and pledges. Together these pathways provide illustrations of potential future 39 developments that can be shaped by human choices, including: Where are current policies and pledges 40 leading us? What is needed to reach specific temperature goals? What are the consequences of using 41 different strategies to meet these goals? What are the consequences of delay? How can we shift 42 development from current practices to give higher priority to sustainability and the SDGs? 43 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-40 Total pages: 142 Each of the IMPs comprises: a storyline and a quantitative illustration. The storyline describes the key 1 characteristics of the pathway qualitatively; the quantitative illustration is selected from the literature 2 on long-term scenarios to effectively represent the IMP numerically. The five Illustrative Mitigation 3 Pathways (IMPs) each emphasise a different scenario element as its defining feature, and are named 4 accordingly: heavy reliance on renewables (IMP-Ren), strong emphasis on low demand for energy 5 (IMP-LD), extensive use of Carbon Dioxide Removal (CDR) in the energy and the industry sectors to 6 achieve net negative emissions (IMP-Neg), mitigation in the context of broader sustainable 7 development and shifting development pathways (IMP-SP), and the implications of a less rapid and 8 gradual strengthening of near-term mitigation actions (IMP-GS). In some cases, sectoral chapters may 9 use different quantifications that follow the same storyline narrative but contain data that better 10 exemplify the chapter’s assessment. Some IMP variants are also used to explore the sensitivity around 11 alternative temperature goals. 12 The two additional pathways illustrative of higher emissions are current policies (CurPol) and moderate 13 action (ModAct). 14 This framework is summarised in Box TS.5 Table.1 below, which also shows where the IMPs are 15 situated with respect to the classification of emissions scenarios into warming levels (C1-C8) introduced 16 in Chapter 3, and the CMIP6 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6) scenarios used in the AR6 17 WG I report. 18 19 Box TS.5 Table.1 Illustrative Mitigation Pathways (IMPs) and pathways illustrative of higher emissions in 20 relation to scenarios’ categories, and CMIP6 scenarios 21 22 Classification of emissions scenarios into warming levels: C1-C8 Pathways illustrative of higher emissions Illustrative mitigation pathways (IMPs) CMIP 6 scenarios C8 (above 4°C) SSP5-8.5 C7 (below 4°C) CurPol SSP3-7.0 C6 (below 3°C) ModAct SSP2-4.5 C5 (below 2.5°C) SSP4-3.7 C4 (below 2°C) C3 (likely below 2°C) IMP-GS (Sensitivities: Neg; Ren) SSP2-2.6 C2 (below 1.5°C; large overshoot) IMP-Neg C1 (below 1.5°C; no or limited overshoot) IMP-LD IMP-Ren IMP-SP SSP1-1.9 23 The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) 24 First published in 2017, the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) are alternative projections of 25 socio-economic developments that may influence future GHG emissions. 26 The initial set of SSP narratives described worlds with different challenges to mitigation and adaptation: 27 SSP1 (sustainability), SSP2 (middle of the road), SSP3 (regional rivalry), SSP4 (inequality) and SSP5 28 (rapid growth). (Box TS.7) 37 38 39 START BOX TS.6 HERE 40 Box TS.6: Understanding net zero CO2 and net zero GHG emissions 41 Reaching net zero CO2 emissions* globally along with reductions in other GHG emissions is necessary 42 to halt global warming at any level. At the point of net zero, the amount of CO2 human activity is putting 43 into the atmosphere equals the amount of CO2 human activity is removing from the atmosphere. 44 Reaching and sustaining net zero CO2 emissions globally would stabilise CO2-induced warming. 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-49 Total pages: 142 Moving to net negative CO2 emissions globally would reduce peak cumulative net CO2 emissions – 1 which occurs at the time of reaching net zero CO2 emissions – and lead to a peak and decline in CO2-2 induced warming. 3 Reaching net zero CO2 emissions sooner can reduce cumulative CO2 emissions and result in less human-4 induced global warming. Overall human-induced warming depends not only on CO2 emissions but also 5 on the contribution from other anthropogenic climate forcers, including aerosols and other GHGs (e.g. 6 CH4 and F-gases). To halt total human-induced warming, emissions of other GHG, in particular CH4, 7 need to be strongly reduced. 8 In the AR6 scenario database, global emissions pathways limiting warming to 1.5°C with no or limited 9 overshoot reach net zero CO2 emissions between 2055-2060 (2035-2090) (median and 5-95th percentile 10 ranges; 100% of pathways); pathways likely to limit warming to 2°C reach net zero CO2 emissions 11 between 2070-2075 (2055-2100) (median and 5-95th percentile ranges; 90% of pathways). This is later 12 than assessed in the AR6 SR1.5 primarily due to more pathways in the literature that approach net-zero 13 CO2 emissions more gradually after a rapid decline of emissions until 2040. (Box TS.6 Figure 1) 14 It does not mean that the world has more time for emissions reductions while still limiting warming to 15 1.5C than reported in the SR15. It only means that the exact timing of reaching net zero CO2 after a 16 steep decline of CO2 emissions until 2040 can show some variation. The SR1.5 median value of 2050 17 is still close to the middle of the current range. If emissions are reduced less rapidly in the period up to 18 2030, an earlier net-zero year is needed. 19 Reaching net zero GHG emissions requires net negative CO2 emissions to balance residual CH4, N2O 20 and F-gas emissions. If achieved globally, net zero GHG emissions would reduce global warming from 21 an earlier peak. Around half global emission pathways limiting warming to 1.5°C, and a third of 22 pathways likely to limit warming to 2°C, reach net zero GHG emissions (based on GWP100) in the 23 second half of the century, around 10-40 years later than net zero CO2 emissions. They show warming 24 being halted at some peak value followed by a gradual decline towards the end of the century. The 25 remainder of the pathways do not reach net zero GHG emissions during the 21st century and show little 26 decline of warming after it stabilised. 27 Global net zero CO2 or GHG emissions can be achieved even while some sectors and regions continue 28 to be net emitters, provided that others achieve net GHG removal. Sectors and regions have different 29 potentials and costs to achieve net zero or even net GHG removal. The adoption and implementation of 30 net zero emission targets by countries and regions depends on multiple factors, including equity and 31 capacity criteria and international and cross-sectoral mechanisms to balance emissions and removals. 32 The formulation of net zero pathways by countries will benefit from clarity on scope, plans-of-action, 33 and fairness. In the majority of studies that have produced the 6 body of work on the cost of mitigation assessed in this report, a CEA approach is adopted, and the 7 feedbacks of climate change impacts on the economic development pathways are not accounted for. 8 This omission of climate impacts leads to overly optimistic economic projections in the reference 9 scenarios, in particular in reference scenarios with no or limited mitigation action where the extent of 10 global warming is the greatest. Mitigation cost estimates computed against no or limited policy 11 reference scenarios therefore omit economic benefits brought by avoided climate change impact along 12 mitigation pathways. 13 The difference in aggregate economic impacts from climate change between two given temperature 14 levels represents the aggregate economic benefits arising from avoided climate change impacts due to 15 mitigation action. Estimates of these benefits vary widely, depending on the methodology used and 16 impacts included, as well as on assumed socioeconomic development conditions, which shape exposure 17 and vulnerability. The aggregate economic benefits of avoiding climate impacts increase with the 18 stringency of the mitigation. Global economic impact studies with regional estimates find large 19 differences across regions, with developing and transitional economies typically more vulnerable. 20 Furthermore, avoided impacts for poorer households and poorer countries represent a smaller share in 21 aggregate quantifications expressed in GDP terms or monetary terms, compared to their influence on 22 well-being and welfare (high confidence
    ). 23 CBA analysis and CBA integrated assessment models remain limited in their ability to represent all 24 damages from climate change, including non-monetary damages, and capture the uncertain and 25 heterogeneous nature of damages and the risk of catastrophic damages, such that other lines of evidence 26 should be considered in decision-making. However, emerging evidence suggests that, even without 27 accounting for co-benefits of mitigation on other sustainable development dimensions, the global 28 benefits of pathways likely to limit warming to 2°C outweigh global mitigation costs over the 21st 29 century (medium confidence
    ). Depending on the study, the reason for this result lies in assumptions of 30 economic damages from climate change in the higher end of available estimates, in the consideration 31 of risks of tipping-points or damages to natural capital and non-market goods, or in the combination of 32 updated representations of carbon cycle and climate modules, updated damage estimates and updated 33 representations of economic and mitigation dynamics. In the studies that perform a sensitivity analysis, 34 this result is found to be robust to a wide range of assumptions on social preferences (in particular on 35 inequality aversion and pure rate of time preference), and holds except if assumptions of economic 36 damages from climate change are in the lower end of available estimates and the pure rate of time 37 preference is in the higher range of values usually considered (typically above 1.5%). (Box TS.8) 26 27 START BOX TS.8 HERE 28 Box TS. 8: Stranded Assets 29 Limiting warming to 2°C or 1.5°C is expected to result in the “stranding” of carbon-intensive 30 assets. Stranded assets can be broadly defined as assets which “suffer from unanticipated or premature 31 write-offs, downward revaluations or conversion to liabilities”. Climate policies, other policies and 32 regulations, innovation in competing technologies, and shifts in fuel prices could all lead to stranded 33 assets. The loss of wealth from stranded assets would create risks for financial market 34 stability, reduce fiscal revenue for hydrocarbon dependent economies, in turn affecting macro-35 economic stability and the prospects for a just transition. (Box TS.4) 36 Two types of assets are at risk of being stranded: i) in-ground fossil resources and ii) human-made 37 capital assets (e.g., power plants, cars). About 30% of oil, 50% of gas, and 80% of coal reserves will 38 remain unburnable if warming is limited to 2°C. 39 Practically all long-lived technologies and investments that cannot be adapted to low-carbon and zero-40 emission modes could face stranding under climate policy – depending on their current age and 41 expected lifetimes. Scenario evidence suggests that without carbon capture, the worldwide fleet of coal- 42 and gas power plants would need to retire about 23 and 17 years earlier than expected lifetimes, 43 respectively in order to limit global warming to 1.5°C and 2°C {2.7}. Blast furnaces and cement 44 factories without CCS , new fleets of airplanes and internal combustion engine vehicles {10.4, 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-54 Total pages: 142 10.5}, and new urban infrastructures adapted to sprawl and motorisation may also be stranded 1 . 2 Many countries, businesses, and individuals stand to lose wealth from stranded assets. Countries, 3 businesses, and individuals may therefore desire to keep assets in operation even if financial, social, or 4 environmental concerns call for retirement. This creates political economic risks, including actions by 5 asset owners to hinder climate policy reform . It will be easier to retire these assets 6 if the risks are communicated, if sustainability reporting is mandated and enforced, and if 7 corporations are protected with arrangements that shield them from short-term shareholder value 8 maximisation. 9 Without early retirements, or reductions in utilisation, the current fossil infrastructure will emit more 10 GHGs than is compatible with limiting warming to 1.5°C {2.7}. Including the pipeline of planned 11 investments would push these future emissions into the uncertainty range of 2°C carbon budgets . 12 Continuing to build new coal-fired power plants and other fossil infrastructure will increase future 13 transition costs and may jeopardize efforts to likely limit warming to 2°C or 1.5°C with no or limited 14 overshoot. One study has estimated that USD11.8 trillion in current assets will need to be stranded by 15 2050 for 2°C world; further delaying action for another 10 years would result in an additional USD7.7 16 trillion in stranded assets by 2050. 17 Experience from past stranding indicates that compensation for the devaluation costs of private sector 18 stakeholders by the public sector is common. Limiting new investments in fossil technologies hence 19 also reduces public finance risks in the long term. 20 END BOX TS.8 HERE 21 22 A low-carbon energy transition will shift investment patterns and create new economic 23 opportunities (high confidence
    ). Total energy investment needs will rise, relative to today, over the 24 next decades, if it is to be likely that warming is limited to 2°C, or if warming is limited to 1.5°C with 25 no or limited overshoot. These increases will be far less pronounced, however, than the reallocations of 26 investment flows that are anticipated across sub-sectors, namely from fossil fuels (extraction, 27 conversion, and electricity generation) without CCS and toward renewables, nuclear power, CCS, 28 electricity networks and storage, and end-use energy efficiency. A significant and growing share of 29 investments between now and 2050 will be made in emerging economies, particularly in Asia. 30 Climate change will affect many future local and national low-carbon energy systems. The 31 impacts, however, are uncertain, particularly at the regional scale (high confidence
    ). Climate 32 change will alter hydropower production, bioenergy and agricultural yields, thermal power plant 33 efficiencies, and demands for heating and cooling, and it will directly impact power system 34 infrastructure. Climate change will not affect wind and solar resources to the extent that it would 35 compromise their ability to reduce emissions. 36 Electricity systems powered predominantly by renewables will be increasingly viable over the 37 coming decades, but it will be challenging to supply the entire energy system with renewable 38 energy (high confidence
    ). Large shares of variable solar PV and wind power can be incorporated in 39 electricity grids through batteries, hydrogen, and other forms of storage; transmission; flexible non-40 renewable generation; advanced controls; and greater demand-side responses. Because some 41 applications (e.g., aviation) are not currently amenable to electrification, it is anticipated that 100% 42 renewable energy systems will need to include alternative fuels such as hydrogen or biofuels. Economic, 43 regulatory, social, and operational challenges increase with higher shares of renewable electricity and 44 energy. The ability to overcome these challenges in practice is not fully understood. (Box TS.9) 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-55 Total pages: 142 START BOX TS.9 HERE 1 2 Box TS.9: The Transformation in Energy Carriers: Electrification and Hydrogen 3 To use energy, it must be “carried” from where it was produced – at a power plant, for example, or a 4 refinery, or a coal mine – to where it is used. As countries reduce CO2 emissions, they will need to 5 switch from gasoline and other petroleum-based fuels, natural gas, coal, and electricity produced from 6 these fossil fuels to energy carriers with little or no carbon footprint. An important question is which 7 new energy carriers will emerge to support low-carbon transitions. 8 Low-carbon energy systems are expected to rely heavily on end-use electrification, where electricity 9 produced with low GHG emissions is used for building and industrial heating, transport and other 10 applications that rely heavily on fossil fuels at present. But not all end-uses are expected to be 11 commercially electrifiable in the short to medium term , and many will require low GHG liquid 12 and gaseous fuels, i.e., hydrogen, ammonia, and biogenic and synthetic low GHG hydrocarbons made 13 from low GHG hydrogen, oxygen and carbon sources (the latter from CCU16, biomass, or direct air 14 capture ). The future role of hydrogen and hydrogen derivatives will depend on how quickly 15 and how far production technology improves, i.e. from electrolysis (“green”), biogasification, and fossil 16 fuel reforming with CCS (“blue”) sources. As a general rule, and across all sectors, it is more efficient 17 to use electricity directly and avoid the progressively larger conversion losses from producing hydrogen, 18 ammonia, or constructed low GHG hydrocarbons. What hydrogen does do, however, is add time and 19 space option value to electricity produced using variable clean sources, for use as hydrogen, as stored 20 future electricity via a fuel cell or turbine, or as an industrial feedstock. Furthermore, electrification and 21 hydrogen involve a symbiotic range of general-purpose technologies, such as electric motors, power 22 electronics, heat pumps, batteries, electrolysis, fuel cells etc., that have different applications across 23 sectors but cumulative economies of innovation and production scale benefits. Finally, neither 24 electrification nor hydrogen produce local air pollutants at point of end-use. 25 For almost 140 years we have primarily produced electricity by burning coal, oil, and gas to drive steam 26 turbines connected to electricity generators. When switching to low-carbon energy sources – renewable 27 sources, nuclear power, and fossil or bioenergy with CCS – electricity is expected to become a more 28 pervasive energy carrier. Electricity is a versatile energy carrier, with much higher end-use efficiencies 29 than fuels, and it can be used directly to avoid conversion losses. 30 An increasing reliance on electricity from variable renewable sources, notably wind and solar power, 31 disrupts old concepts and makes many existing guidelines obsolete for power system planning, e.g., 32 that specific generation types are needed for baseload, intermediate load, and peak load to follow and 33 meet demand. In future power systems with high shares of variable electricity from renewable sources, 34 system planning and markets will focus more on demand flexibility, grid infrastructure and 35 interconnections, storage on various timelines (on the minute, hourly, overnight and seasonal scale), 36 and increased coupling between the energy sector and the building, transport and industrial sectors. This 37 shifts the focus to energy systems that can handle variable supply rather than always follow demand. 38 Hydrogen may prove valuable to improve the resilience of electricity systems with high penetration of 39 variable renewable electricity. Flexible hydrogen electrolysis, hydrogen power plants and long-duration 40 hydrogen storage may all improve resilience. Electricity-to-hydrogen-to-electricity round-trip 41 efficiencies are projected to reach up to 50% by 2030. 42 FOOTNOTE16Carbon dioxide capture and utilisation (CCU) refers to a process in which CO2is captured and the carbon is then used in a product. The climate effect of CCU depends on the product lifetime, the product it displaces, and the CO2source (fossil, biomass or atmosphere). CCU is sometimes referred to as Carbon Dioxide Capture and Use, or Carbon Capture and Utilisation. AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-56 Total pages: 142 Electrification is expected to be the dominant strategy in buildings as electricity is increasingly used for 1 heating and for cooking. Electricity will help to integrate renewable energy into buildings and will also 2 lead to more flexible demand for heating, cooling, and electricity. District heating and cooling offers 3 potential for demand flexibility through energy storage and supply flexibility through cogeneration. 4 Heat pumps are increasingly used in buildings and industry for heating and cooling {9.3.3, Box 9.3}. 5 The ease of switching to electricity means that hydrogen is not expected to be a dominant pathway for 6 buildings . Using electricity directly for heating, cooling and other building energy demand 7 is more efficient than using hydrogen as a fuel, for example, in boilers or fuel cells. In addition, 8 electricity distribution is already well developed in many regions compared to essentially non-existent 9 hydrogen infrastructure, except for a few chemicals industry pipelines. At the same time, hydrogen 10 could potentially be used for on-site storage should technology advance sufficiently. 11 Electrification is already occurring in several modes of personal and light freight transport, and vehicle-12 to-grid solutions for flexibility have been extensively explored in the literature and small-scale pilots. 13 The role of hydrogen in transport depends on how far technology develops. Batteries are currently a 14 more attractive option than hydrogen and fuel-cells for light-duty vehicles. Most building sector emissions are CO2. Over the period 1990-2019, 9 global CO2 emissions from buildings increased by 50%, global final energy demand from buildings 10 grew by 38% and global final electricity demand increased by 161%. 11 In most regions, historical improvements in efficiency have been approximately matched by 12 growth in floor area per capita (high confidence
