At the global level, building specific drivers of 13 GHG emissions include: (i) population growth, especially in developing countries; (ii) increasing floor 14 area per capita, driven by the increasing size of dwellings while the size of households kept decreasing, 15 especially in developed countries; (iii) the inefficiency of newly constructed buildings, especially in 16 developing countries, and the low renovation rates and low ambition level in developed countries when 17 existing buildings are renovated; iv) the increase in use, number and size of appliances and equipment, 18 especially Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) and cooling, driven by income; and, 19 (v) the continued reliance on carbon intensive electricity and heat. These factors taken together are 20 projected to continue driving increased GHG emissions in the building sector in the future. 22 Building sector GHG emissions were assessed using the Sufficiency, Efficiency, Renewable (SER) 23 framework. Sufficiency measures tackle the causes of GHG emissions by limiting the demand for 24 energy and materials over the lifecycle of buildings and appliances (high confidence
    ). In Chapter 25 9 of this report, sufficiency differs from efficiency. Sufficiency is about long-term actions driven by non-26 technological solutions, which consume less energy in absolute terms. Efficiency, in contrast is about 27 continuous short-term marginal technological improvements. Use of the SER framework reduces the 28 cost of constructing and using buildings without reducing occupant’s well-being and comfort. 30 Sufficiency interventions do not consume energy during the use phase of buildings and do not 31 require maintenance nor replacement over the lifetime of buildings. Density, compacity, 32 bioclimatic design to optimise the use of nature-based solutions, multi-functionality of space through 33 shared space and to allow for adjusting the size of buildings to the evolving needs of households, 34 circular use of materials and repurposing unused existing buildings to avoid using virgin materials, 35 optimisation of the use of buildings through lifestyle changes, use of the thermal mass of buildings to 36 reduce thermal needs, moving from ownership to usership of appliances are among the sufficiency 37 interventions implemented in leading municipalities (high confidence
    ). At a global level, up to 17% of 38 the mitigation potential in the buildings sector could be captured by 2050 through sufficiency 39 interventions (medium confidence
    ). (Figure TS. 15) . 40 The potential associated with sufficiency measures, as well as the replacement of appliances, 41 equipment and lights by efficient ones, is below zero cost (high confidence
    ). The construction of 42 high-performance buildings is expected to become a business-as-usual technology by 2050 with costs 43 below USD20 tCO2 -1in developed countries and below USD100 tCO2 -1in developing countries 44 (medium confidence
    ). For existing buildings, there have been many examples of deep retrofits where 45 additional costs per CO2 abated are not significantly higher than those of shallow retrofits.     . 5 6 Net zero CO2 industrial sector emissions are possible but challenging (high confidence
    Energy 7 efficiency will continue to be important. Reduced materials demand, material efficiency, and circular 8 economy solutions can reduce the need for primary production. Primary production options include 9 switching to new processes that use low to zero GHG energy carriers and feedstocks (e.g., electricity, 10 hydrogen, biofuels, and carbon dioxide capture and utilisation (CCU) to provide carbon feedstocks). 11 Carbon capture and storage (CCS) will be required to mitigate remaining CO2 emissions . These 12 options require substantial scaling up of electricity, hydrogen, recycling, CO2, and other infrastructure, 13 as well as phase-out or conversion of existing industrial plants. While improvements in the GHG 14 intensities of major basic materials have nearly stagnated over the last 30 years, analysis of historical 15 technology shifts and newly available technologies indicate these intensities can be significantly 16 reduced by mid-century. 17 Industry sector emissions have been growing faster since 2000 than emissions in any other sector, 18 driven by increased basic materials extraction and production (high confidence
    . GHG emissions 19 attributed to the industrial sector originate from fuel combustion, process emissions, product use and 20 waste, which jointly accounted for 14.1 GtCO2-eq or 24% of all direct anthropogenic emissions in 2019, 21 second behind the energy supply sector. Industry is a leading GHG emitter - 20 GtCO2-eq or 34% of 22 global emissions in 2019 - if indirect emissions from power and heat generation are included. The share 23 of emissions originating from direct fuel combustion is decreasing and was 7 GtCO2-eq, 50% of direct 24 industrial emissions in 2019. 25 Global material intensity – the in-use stock of manufactured capital in tonnes per unit of GDP– 26 is increasing (high confidence
    . In-use stock of manufactured capital per capita has been growing 27 faster than GDP per capita since 2000. Total global in-use stock of manufactured capital grew by 3.4% 28 yr-1in 2000–2019. At the same time, per capita material stocks in several developed countries have 29 stopped growing, showing a decoupling from GDP per capita. 30 The demand for plastic has been growing most strongly since 1970 (high confidence
    . The current 31 >99% reliance on fossil feedstock, very low recycling, and high emissions from petrochemical 32 processes is a challenge for reaching net zero emissions. At the same time, plastics are important for 33 reducing emissions elsewhere, for example, light-weighting vehicles.     . Costs and emissions 21 reductions potential in industry, and especially heavy industry, are highly contingent on innovation, 22 commercialisation, and market uptake policies. Technologies exist to take all industry sectors to very 23 low or zero emissions, but require 5–15 years of intensive innovation, commercialisation, and policy to 24 ensure uptake. Mitigation costs are in the rough range of USD50–150 tCO2-eq-1, with wide variation 25 within and outside this band. This affects competitiveness and requires supporting policy. Although 26 production cost increases can be significant, they translate to very small increases in the costs for final 27 products, typically less than a few percent depending on product, assumptions, and system boundaries. 28 (Figure TS.17) 29 Several technological options exist for very low to zero emissions steel, but their uptake will 30 require integrated material efficiency, recycling, and production decarbonisation policies (high 31 confidence). Material efficiency can potentially reduce steel demand by up to 40% based on design for 32 less steel use, long life, reuse, constructability, and low contamination recycling. Secondary production 33 through high quality recycling must be maximised. Production decarbonisation will also be required, 34 starting with the retrofitting of existing facilities for partial fuel switching (e.g., to biomass or hydrogen), 35 CCU and CCS, followed by very low and zero emissions production based on high-capture CCS or 36 direct hydrogen, or electrolytic iron ore reduction followed by an electric arc furnace. 37 Several current and emerging options can significantly reduce cement and concrete emissions. 38 Producer, user, and regulator education, as well as innovation and commercialisation policy are 39 needed (medium confidence
    . Cement and concrete are currently overused because they are 40 inexpensive, durable, and ubiquitous, and consumption decisions typically do not give weight to their 41 production emissions. Basic material efficiency efforts to use only well-made concrete thoughtfully and 42 only where needed (e.g., using right-sized, prefabricated components) could reduce emissions by 24–43 50% through lower demand for clinker. Cementitious material substitution with various materials (e.g., 44 ground limestone and calcined clays) can reduce process calcination emissions by up to 50% and 45 occasionally much more. The character of land 4 occupation, and associated impacts, vary considerably among mitigation options and also for the same 5 option depending on geographic location, scale, system design and deployment strategy. Land 6 occupation can be large uniform areas, e.g., reservoir hydropower dams and tree plantations, and more 7 distributed occupation that is integrated with other land uses, e.g., wind turbines and agroforestry in 8 agriculture landscapes.     ). Such risks can best 16 be managed if AFOLU mitigation is pursued in response to the needs and perspectives of multiple 17 stakeholders to achieve outcomes that maximise synergies while limiting trade-offs (medium 18 confidence). The results of implementing AFOLU measures are often variable and highly context 19 specific. Depending on local conditions (e.g., ecosystem, climate, food system, land ownership) and 20 management strategies (e.g., scale, method), mitigation measures can positively or negatively affect 21 biodiversity, ecosystem functioning, air quality, water availability and quality, soil productivity, rights 22 infringements, food security, and human well-being. The agriculture and forestry sectors can devise 23 management approaches that enable biomass production and use for energy in conjunction with the 24 production of food and timber, thereby reducing the conversion pressure on natural ecosystems (medium 25 confidence). Mitigation measures addressing GHGs may also affect other climate forcers such as albedo 26 and evapotranspiration. Integrated responses that contribute to mitigation, adaptation, and other land 27 challenges will have greater likelihood of being successful (high confidence
    ); measures which provide 28 additional benefits to biodiversity and human well-being are sometimes described as ‘Nature-based 29 Solutions’. 30 AFOLU mitigation measures have been well understood for decades but deployment remains 31 slow, and emissions trends indicate unsatisfactory progress despite beneficial contributions to 32 global emissions reduction from forest-related options (high confidence
    ). Globally, the AFOLU 33 sector has so far contributed modestly to net mitigation, as past policies have delivered about 0.65 34 GtCO2 yr-1of mitigation during 2010–2019 or 1.4% of global gross emissions. The majority (>80%) of 35 emission reduction resulted from forestry measures. Although the mitigation potential of AFOLU 36 measures is large from a biophysical and ecological perspective, its feasibility is hampered by lack of 37 institutional support, uncertainty over long-term additionality and trade-offs, weak governance, 38 fragmented land ownership, and uncertain permanence effects. Despite these impediments to change, 39 AFOLU mitigation options are demonstrably effective and with appropriate support can enable rapid 40 emission reductions in most countries. 41 Concerted, rapid and sustained effort by all stakeholders, from policy makers and investors to 42 land-owners and managers is a pre-requisite for achieving high levels of mitigation in the AFOLU 43 sector (high confidence
    ). To date USD0.7 billion yr-1is estimated to have been spent on AFOLU 44 mitigation. This is well short of the more than USD400 billion yr-1that is estimated to be necessary to 45 deliver the up to 30% of global mitigation effort envisaged in deep mitigation scenarios (medium 46 confidence). This estimate of the global funding requirement is smaller than current subsidies provided 47 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-88 Total pages: 142to agriculture and forestry. A gradual redirection of existing agriculture and forestry subsidies would 1 greatly advance mitigation. Effective policy interventions and national (investment) plans as part of 2 NDCs, specific to local circumstances and needs, are urgently needed to accelerate the deployment of 3 AFOLU mitigation options. These interventions are effective when they include funding schemes and 4 long-term consistent support for implementation with governments taking the initiative together with 5 private funders and non-state actors. 6 Realising the mitigation potential of the AFOLU sector depends strongly on policies that directly 7 address emissions and drive the deployment of land-based mitigation options, consistent with 8 carbon prices in deep mitigation scenarios (high confidence
    ). Examples of successful policies and 9 measures include establishing and respecting tenure rights and community forestry, improved 10 agricultural management and sustainable intensification, biodiversity conservation, payments for 11 ecosystem services, improved forest management and wood chain usage, bioenergy, voluntary supply 12 chain management efforts, consumer behaviour campaigns, private funding and joint regulatory efforts 13 to avoid e.g., leakage. The efficacy of different policies, however, will depend on numerous region-14 specific factors. In addition to funding, these factors include governance, institutions, long-term 15 consistent execution of measures, and the specific policy setting. While the governance of land-based 16 mitigation can draw on lessons from previous experience with regulating biofuels and forest carbon 17 integrating these insights requires governance that goes beyond project-level approaches emphasising 18 integrated land use planning and management within the frame of the sustainable development goals. 19 20 Addressing the many knowledge gaps in the development and testing of AFOLU mitigation 21 options can rapidly advance the likelihood of achieving sustained mitigation (high confidence
    ). 22 Research priorities include improved quantification of anthropogenic and natural GHG fluxes and 23 emissions modelling, better understanding of the impacts of climate change on the mitigation potential, 24 permanence and additionality of estimated mitigation actions, and improved (real time and cheap) 25 measurement, reporting and verification. There is a need to include a greater suite of mitigation 26 measures in IAMs, informed by more realistic assessments that take into account local circumstances 27 and socio-economic factors and cross-sector synergies and trade-offs. Finally, there is a critical need 28 for more targeted research to develop appropriate country-level, locally specific, policy and land 29 management response options.     23-42% of global GHG emissions are associated with food systems, while 36 there is still wide-spread food insecurity and malnutrition. Absolute GHG emissions from food systems 37 increased from 14 to 17 GtCO2-eq yr-1in the period 1990-2018. Both supply and demand side measures 38 are important to reduce the GHG intensity of food systems. Integrated food policy packages based on a 39 combination of market-based, administrative, informative, and behavioural policies can reduce cost 40 compared to uncoordinated interventions, address multiple sustainability goals, and increase acceptance 41 across stakeholders and civil society (limited evidence, medium agreement). Food systems governance 42 may be pioneered through local food policy initiatives complemented by national and international 43 initiatives, but governance on the national level tends to be fragmented, and thus have limited capacity 44 to address structural issues like inequities in access. CDR is also an essential element 33 of scenarios that limit warming to 1.5°C or likely below 2°C by 2100, regardless of whether global 34 emissions reach near zero, net zero or net negative levels. While national mitigation portfolios aiming 35 at net zero emissions or lower will need to include some level of CDR, the choice of methods and the 36 scale and timing of their deployment will depend on the achievement of gross emission reductions, and 37 managing multiple sustainability and feasibility constraints, including political preferences and social 38 acceptability. 39 CDR refers to anthropogenic activities removing CO2 from the atmosphere and durably storing it in 40 geological, terrestrial, or ocean reservoirs, or in products. It includes existing and potential 41 anthropogenic enhancement of biological, geochemical or chemical CO2 sinks, but excludes natural 42 CO2 uptake not directly caused by human activities (Annex I). Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) and 43 FOOTNOTE 22As a median value (5 to 95% range). AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-95 Total pages: 142Carbon Capture and Utilisation (CCU) applied to fossil CO2 do not count as removal technologies. CCS 1 and CCU can only be part of CDR methods if the CO2 is biogenic or directly captured from ambient 2 air, and stored durably in geological reservoirs or products. 3 There is a great variety of CDR methods and respective implementation options . Some of these methods (like afforestation and soil-carbon sequestration) have 5 been practiced for decades to millennia, although not necessarily with the intention to remove carbon 6 from the atmosphere. Conversely, for methods such as DACCS and BECCS, experience is growing but 7 still limited in scales. A categorisation of CDR methods can be based on several criteria, depending on 8 the highlighted characteristics. In this report, the categorisation is focused on the role of CDR methods 9 in the carbon cycle, i.e. on the removal process (land-based biological; ocean-based biological; 10 geochemical; chemical) and on the timescale of storage (decades to centuries; centuries to millennia; 11 10 thousand years or longer), the latter being closely linked to different carbon storage media. Within 12 one category (e.g., ocean-based biological CDR) options often differ with respect to other dynamic or 13 context-specific dimensions such as mitigation potential, cost, potential for co-benefits and adverse 14 side-effects, and technology readiness level. (Table TS.7; TS 5.6, 5.7) 15 It is useful to distinguish between CO2 removal from the atmosphere as the outcome of deliberate 16 activities implementing CDR options, and the net emissions outcome achieved with the help of CDR 17 deployment (i.e., gross emissions minus gross removals). As part of ambitious mitigation strategies at 18 global or national levels, gross CDR can fulfil three different roles in complementing emissions 19 abatement: (1) lowering net CO2 or GHG emissions in the near-term; (2) counterbalancing ‘hard-to-20 abate’ residual emissions like CO2 from industrial activities and long-distance transport, or CH4 and 21 nitrous oxide from agriculture, in order to help reach net zero CO2 or GHG emissions in the mid-term; 22 (3) achieving net negative CO2 or GHG emissions in the long-term if deployed at levels exceeding 23 annual residual emissions . These roles of CDR are not mutually exclusive: for 24 example, achieving net zero CO2 or GHG emissions globally might involve individual developed 25 countries attaining net negative CO2 emissions at the time of global net zero, thereby allowing 26 developing countries a smoother transition. 27 END BOX TS.10 HERE 28 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-96 Total pages: 142Table TS.7: Summary of status, costs, potentials, risk and impacts, co-benefits, trade-offs and spill over effects and the role in mitigation pathways for CDR 1 methods TRL = Technology Readiness Level 2 CDR option Status (TRL) Cost (USD tCO2 -1) Mitigation Potential (GtCO2 yr-1) Risk and Impacts Co-benefits Trade-offs and spill over effects Role in mitigation pathways Section Afforestation/Reforestation (8-9) 0-240 0.5-10 Reversal of carbon removal through wildfire, disease, pests may occur. This 3 provides new insight into climate change mitigation strategies, and how economic and social activity 4 might be organised across sectors to support emission reductions. To enhance well-being, people 5 demand services and not primary energy and physical resources per se. Focusing on demand for services 6 and the different social and political roles people play broadens the participation in climate action. (Box 7 TS.11) 8 Demand-side mitigation and new ways of providing services can help Avoid and Shift final service 9 demands and Improve service delivery. Rapid and deep changes in demand make it easier for 10 every sector to reduce GHG emissions in the short and medium term (high confidence
    ). 11 The indicative potential of demand-side strategies across all sectors to reduce emissions is 40-70% 12 by 2050 (high confidence
    . Technical mitigation potentials compared to the International Energy 13 Agency’s 2020 World Energy Outlook STEPS (Stated Policy Scenarios) baseline are up to 5.7 GtCO2-eq for 14 building use and construction, 8 GtCO2-eq for food demand, 6.5 GtCO2-eq for land transport, and 5.2 15 GtCO2-eq for industry. Mitigation strategies can be classified as Avoid-Shift-Improve (ASI) options, 16 that reflect opportunities for socio-cultural, infrastructural, and technological change. The greatest 17 Avoid potential comes from reducing long-haul aviation and providing short-distance low-carbon urban 18 infrastructures. The greatest Shift potential would come from switching to plant-based diets. The 19 greatest Improve potential comes from within the building sector, and in particular increased use of 20 energy efficient end-use technologies and passive housing. (Figure TS.20, Figure TS.21) 22 Socio-cultural and lifestyle changes can accelerate climate change mitigation (medium 23 confidence). Among 60 identified actions that could change individual consumption, individual 24 mobility choices have the largest potential to reduce carbon footprints. Prioritising car-free mobility by 25 walking and cycling and adoption of electric mobility could save 2 tCO2-eq cap-1 yr-1. Other options 26 with high mitigation potential include reducing air travel, cooling setpoint adjustments, reduced 27 appliance use, shifts to public transit, and shifting consumption towards plant-based diets. 29 30 START BOX TS.11 HERE 31 Box TS.11: A New Chapter in WG III AR6 Focusing on the Social Science of Demand, and 32 Social Aspects of Mitigation 33 The WG III contribution to the Sixth Assessment Report of the IPCC (AR6) features a distinct chapter 34 on demand, services and social aspects of mitigation . The scope, theories, and evidence for such an 35 assessment are addressed in Sections 5.1 and 5.4 within Chapter 5 and a Social Science Primer as an 36 Appendix to Chapter 5. 37 The literature on social science – from sociology, psychology, gender studies and political science for 38 example – and climate change mitigation is growing rapidly. A bibliometric search of the literature 39 identified 99,065 peer-reviewed academic papers, based on 34 search queries with content relevant to 40 Chapter 5. This literature is expanding by 15% per year, with twice as many publications in the AR6 41 period (2014-2020) as in all previous years. 42 The models of stakeholders’ decisions assessed by IPCC have continuously evolved. From AR1 to 43 AR4, rational choice was the implicit assumption: agents with perfect information and unlimited 44 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-99 Total pages: 142processing capacity maximising self-focused expected utility and differing only in wealth, risk attitude, 1 and time discount rate. AR5 introduced a broader range of goals (material, social, and psychological) 2 and decision processes (calculation-based, affect-based, and rule-based processes). However, its 3 perspective was still individual- and agency-focused, neglecting structural, cultural, and institutional 4 constraints and the influence of physical and social context. 5 A social science perspective is important in two ways. By adding new actors and perspectives, it (i) 6 provides more options for climate mitigation; and (ii) helps to identify and address important social and 7 cultural barriers and opportunities to socioeconomic, technological, and institutional change. Demand-8 side mitigation involves five sets of social actors: individuals (e.g., consumption choices, habits), 9 groups and collectives (e.g., social movements, values), corporate actors (e.g., investments, 10 advertising), institutions (e.g., political agency, regulations), and infrastructure actors (e.g., very long-11 term investments and financing). Actors either contribute to the status-quo of a global high-carbon, 12 consumption, and GDP growth-oriented economy, or help generate the desired change to a low-carbon 13 energy-services, well-being, and equity-oriented economy. Each set of actors has novel implications for 14 the design and implementation of both demand- and supply-side mitigation policies. They show 15 important synergies, making energy demand mitigation a dynamic problem where the packaging and/or 16 sequencing of different policies play a role in their effectiveness . Incremental interventions 17 change social practices, simultaneously affecting emissions and well-being. The transformative change 18 requires coordinated action across all five sets of actors (Table 5.4), using social science insights about 19 intersection of behaviour, culture, institutional and infrastructural changes for policy design and 20 implementation. Avoid, Shift, and Improve choices by individuals, households and communities support 21 mitigation . They are instigated by role models, changing social norms driven by 22 policies and social movements. (Box TS.12, Box TS.14) 16 17 START BOX TS.12 HERE 18 Box TS.12: Circular Economy (CE) 19 In AR6, the Circular Economy (CE) concept {Annex I} is highlighted as an increasingly important 20 mitigation approach that can help deliver human well-being by minimising waste of energy and 21 resources. While definitions of CE vary, its essence is to shift away from linear “make and dispose” 22 economic models to those that emphasize product longevity, reuse, refurbishment, recycling, and 23 material efficiency, thereby enabling more circular material systems that reduce embodied energy and 24 emissions. 25 Whereas IPCC AR4 {WG III, Chapter 10} included a separate chapter on waste sector emissions and 26 waste management practices, and AR5 {WG III, Chapter 10} reviewed the importance of “reduce, 27 reuse, recycle” and related policies, AR6 focuses on how CE can reduce waste in materials production 28 and consumption by optimising materials’ end-use service utility. Specific examples of CE 29 implementations, policies, and mitigation potentials are included in chapters 5, 8, 9, 11 and 12. 31 CE is shown to empower new social actors in mitigation actions, given that it relies on the synergistic 32 actions of producers, sellers, and consumers {11.3.3}. As an energy and resource demand-reduction 33 strategy, it is consistent with high levels of human well-being {5.3.4.3} and ensures better 34 environmental quality (Figure TS.22) {5.2.1}. It also creates jobs through increased sharing, reuse, 35 refurbishment, and recycling activities. Therefore, CE contributes to several SDGs, including Clean 36 Water and Sanitation (SDG6), Affordable Energy and Clean Energy (SDG7), Decent Work and 37 Economic Growth (SDG8), Responsible Production and Consumption (SDG12) and Climate Action 38 (SDG13). 39 Emissions savings derive from reduced primary material production and transport. For example, in 40 buildings, lifetime extension, material efficiency, and reusable components reduce embodied emissions 41 by avoiding demand for structural materials {9.3, 9.5}. At regional scales, urban/industrial symbiosis 42 reduce primary material demand through byproduct exchange networks {11.3.3}. CE strategies also 43 exhibit enabling effects, such as material-efficient and circular vehicle designs that also improve fuel 44 economy . There is growing interest in “circular bioeconomy” concepts applied to bio-based 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-103 Total pages: 142materials {Box 12.2} and even a “circular carbon economy”, wherein carbon captured via CCU 1 {11.3.6} or CDR {3.4.6} is converted into reusable materials, which is especially relevant for the 2 transitions of economies dependent on fossil fuel revenue. 3 While there are many recycling policies, CE-oriented policies for more efficient material use with 4 higher value retention are comparatively far fewer; these policy gaps have been attributed to 5 institutional failures, lack of coordination, and lack of strong advocates {5.3, 9.5.3.6, Box 11.5, Box 6 12.2}. Reviews of mitigation potentials reveal unevenness in the savings of CE applications and 7 potential risks of rebound effects . Therefore, CE policies that identify system determinants 8 maximize potential emissions reductions, which vary by material, location, and application. 9 There are knowledge gaps for assessing CE opportunities within mitigation models due to CE’s many 10 cross-sectoral linkages and data gaps related to its nascent state {3.4.4}. Opportunity exists to bridge 11 knowledge from the Industrial Ecology field, which has historically studied CE, to the mitigation 12 modelling community for improved analysis of interventions and policies for AR7. For instance, a 13 global CE knowledge sharing platform is helpful for CE performance measurement, reporting and 14 accounting. 15 END BOX TS.12 HERE 16 17 Providing better services with less energy and resource input has high technical potential and is 18 consistent with providing well-being for all (medium confidence

Carbon leakage occurs when mitigation measures implemented 20 in one country/sector leads to increased emissions in other countries/sectors. Global commodity value 21 chains and associated international transport are important mechanisms through which carbon leakage 22 occurs. Reducing emissions from the value chain and transportation can offer opportunities to mitigate 23 three elements of cross-sectoral spill-overs and related leakage: 1) domestic cross-sectoral spill-overs 24 within the same country; 2) international spill-overs within a single sector resulting from substitution 25 of domestic production of carbon-intensive goods with their imports from abroad; and 3) international 26 cross-sectoral spill-overs among sectors in different countries. 27 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-109 Total pages: 142TS. 6 Implementation and enabling conditions 1 Chapters 13-16 address the enabling conditions that can accelerate or impede rapid progress on 2 mitigation. Chapters 13 and 14 focus on policy, governance and institutional capacity, and international 3 cooperation, respectively taking a national and international perspective; Chapter 15 focusses on 4 investment and finance; and Chapter 16 focusses on innovation and technology. The assessment of 5 social aspects of mitigation draws on material assessed in Chapter 5. 6 TS. 6.1 Policy and Institutions 7 Long-term deep emission reductions, including the reduction of emissions to net zero, is best 8 achieved through institutions and governance that nurture new mitigation policies, while at the 9 same time reconsidering existing policies that support the continued emission of GHGs (high 10 confidence). To do so effectively, the scope of climate governance needs to include both direct efforts 11 to target GHG emissions and indirect opportunities to tackle GHG emissions that result from efforts 12 directed towards other policy objectives. 13 Institutions and governance underpin mitigation by providing the legal basis for action. This 14 includes setting up implementing organisations and the frameworks through which diverse actors 15 interact (medium evidence, high agreement). Institutions can create mitigation and sectoral policy 16 instruments; policy packages for low-carbon system transition; and economy wide measures for 17 systemic restructuring. 18 Policies have had a discernible impact on mitigation for specific countries, sectors, and 19 technologies (high confidence
    ), avoiding emissions of several GtCO2-eq yr-1(medium confidence
    20 Both market-based and regulatory policies have distinct, but complementary roles. The share of global 21 GHG emissions subject to mitigation policy has increased rapidly in recent years, but big gaps remain 22 in policy coverage, and the stringency of many policies falls short of what is needed to achieve the 23 desired mitigation outcomes. (Box TS.13) 24 Climate laws enable mitigation action by signalling the direction of travel, setting targets, 25 mainstreaming mitigation into sector policies, enhancing regulatory certainty, creating law-26 backed agencies, creating focal points for social mobilisation, and attracting international finance 27 (medium evidence, high agreement). By 2020, ‘direct’ climate laws primarily focused on GHG 28 reductions were present in 56 countries covering 53% of global emissions (see Figure TS.24). More 29 than 690 laws, including ‘indirect’ laws, however, may also have an effect on mitigation. Among direct 30 laws, ‘framework’ laws set an overarching legal basis for mitigation either by pursuing a target and 31 implementation approach, or by seeking to mainstream climate objectives through sectoral plans and 32 integrative institutions. (Figure TS.24) 33 Institutions can enable improved governance by coordinating across sectors, scales and actors, 34 building consensus for action, and setting strategies (medium evidence, high agreement). 35 Institutions are more stable and effective when they are congruent with national contexts, leading to 36 mitigation-focused institutions in some countries and the pursuit of multiple objectives in others. Sub-37 national institutions play a complementary role to national institutions by developing locally-relevant 38 visions and plans, addressing policy gaps or limits in national institutions, building local administrative 39 structures and convening actors for place-based decarbonisation. 40 Mitigation strategies, instruments and policies that fit with dominant ideas, values and belief 41 systems within a country or within a sector are more easily adopted and implemented (medium 42 confidence). Ideas, values and beliefs may change over time. Policies that bring perceived direct 43 benefits, such as subsidies, usually receive greater support. The awareness of co-benefits for the public 44 increases support of climate policies (high confidence
    ). 45 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-110 Total pages: 1421 Panel a 2 3 Panel b 4 5 6 Figure TS.24: Prevalence of Legislation and Emissions Targets across Regions 7 8 Figure TS.24 legend: Panel a: Shares of global GHG emissions under national climate change legislations – in 9 2010, 2015 and 2020. AR6 regions: DEV = Developed countries; APC = Asia and developing Pacific; 19 EEA = Eastern Europe and West-Central Asia; AFR = Africa; LAM = Latin America and the Caribbean; MDE 20 = Middle East. 21 . 22 Climate governance is constrained and enabled by domestic structural factors, but it is still 23 possible for actors to make substantial changes (medium evidence, high agreement). Key structural 24 factors are domestic material endowments (such as fossil fuels and land-based resources); domestic 25 political systems; and prevalent ideas, values and belief systems. Developing countries face additional 26 material constraints in climate governance due to development challenges and scarce economic or 27 natural resources. A broad group of actors influence how climate governance develop over time, 28 including a range of civic organisations, encompassing both pro- and anti-climate action groups. 30 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-111 Total pages: 142Sub-national actors are important for mitigation because municipalities and regional 1 governments have jurisdiction over climate-relevant sectors such as land-use, waste and urban 2 policy. They are able to experiment with climate solutions and can forge partnerships with the 3 private sector and internationally to leverage enhanced climate action (high confidence
    ). More 4 than 10,500 cities and nearly 250 regions representing more than 2 billion people have pledged largely 5 voluntary action to reduce emissions. Indirect gains include innovation, establishing norms and 6 developing capacity. However, sub-national actors often lack national support, funding, and capacity to 7 mobilize finance and human resources, and create new institutional competences. 8 Climate litigation is growing and can affect the outcome and ambition of climate governance 9 (medium evidence, high agreement). Since 2015, at least 37 systemic cases have been initiated against 10 states that challenge the overall effort of a state to mitigate or adapt to climate change. If successful, 11 such cases can lead to an increase in a country’s overall ambition to tackle climate change. Climate 12 litigation has also successfully challenged governments’ authorisations of high-emitting projects setting 13 precedents in favour of climate action. Climate litigation against private sector and financial institutions 14 is also on the rise. 15 The media shapes the public discourse about climate mitigation. This can usefully build public 16 support to accelerate mitigation action but may also be used to impede decarbonisation (medium 17 evidence, high agreement). Global media coverage (across a study of 59 countries) has been growing, 18 from about 47,000 articles in 2016-17 to about 87,000 in 2020-21. Generally, the media representation 19 of climate science has increased and become more accurate over time. On occasion, the propagation of 20 scientifically misleading information by organized counter-movements has fuelled polarisation, with 21 negative implications for climate policy. 22 Explicit attention to equity and justice is salient to both social acceptance and fair and effective 23 policymaking for mitigation (high confidence
    ). Distributional implications of alternative climate 24 policy choices can be usefully evaluated at city, local and national scales as an input to policymaking. 25 It is anticipated that institutions and governance frameworks that enable consideration of justice and 26 just transitions can build broader support for climate policymaking. 27 Carbon pricing is effective in promoting implementation of low-cost emissions reductions (high 28 confidence). While the coverage of emissions trading and carbon taxes has risen to over 20 percent of 29 global CO2 emissions, both coverage and price are lower than is needed for deep reductions. Market 30 mechanisms ideally are designed to be effective as well as efficient, balance distributional goals and 31 find social acceptance. Practical experience has driven progress in market mechanism design, especially 32 of emissions trading schemes. Carbon pricing is limited in its effect on adoption of higher-cost 33 mitigation options, and where decisions are often not sensitive to price incentives such as in energy 34 efficiency, urban planning, and infrastructure (robust evidence, medium agreement). Subsidies have 35 been used to improve energy efficiency, encourage the uptake of renewable energy and other sector-36 specific emissions saving options 37 Carbon pricing is most effective if revenues are redistributed or used impartially (high 38 confidence). A carbon levy earmarked for green infrastructures or saliently returned to taxpayers 39 corresponding to widely accepted notions of fairness increases the political acceptability of carbon 40 pricing. 41 Removing fossil fuel subsidies could reduce emissions by 1-10% by 2030 while improving public 42 revenue and macroeconomic performance (robust evidence, medium agreement). 43 Regulatory instruments play an important role in achieving specific mitigation outcomes in 44 sectoral applications (high confidence
    ). Regulation is effective in particular applications and often 45 enjoys greater political support, but tends to be more economically costly, than pricing instruments 46 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSTS-112 Total pages: 142(robust evidence, medium agreement). Flexible forms of regulation (e.g., performance standards) have 1 achieved aggregate goals for renewable energy generation, vehicle efficiency and fuel standards, and 2 energy efficiency in buildings and industry. Infrastructure investment decisions are significant for 3 mitigation because they lock in high- or low- emissions trajectories over long periods. Information and 4 voluntary programs can contribute to overall mitigation outcomes (medium evidence, high agreement). 5 Designing for overlap and interactions among mitigation policies enhances their effectiveness. 6 National mitigation policies interact internationally with effects that both support and hinder 7 mitigation action (medium evidence, high agreement). Reductions in demand for fossil fuels tend to 8 negatively affect fossil fuel exporting countries. Creation of markets for emission reduction credits 9 tends to benefit countries able to supply credits. Policies to support technology development and 10 diffusion tend to have positive spill over effects. There is no consistent evidence of significant emissions 11 leakage or competitiveness effects between countries, including for emissions-intensive trade-exposed 12 industries covered by emission trading systems (medium confidence
    . 13 Policy packages are better able to support socio-technical transitions and shifts in development 14 pathways toward low carbon futures than are individual policies (high confidence
    ). For best effect, 15 they need to be harnessed to a clear vision for change and designed with attention to local governance 16 context. Comprehensiveness in coverage, coherence to ensure complementarity, and consistency of 17 policies with the overarching vision and its objectives are important design criteria. Integration across 18 objectives occurs when a policy package is informed by a clear problem framing and identification of 19 the full range of relevant policy sub-systems. The climate policy landscape is outlined in Table TS.8, 20 which maps framings of desired national policy outcomes to policymaking approaches. 22 The co-benefits and trade-offs of integrating adaptation and mitigation are most usefully 23 identified and assessed prior to policy making rather than being accidentally discovered (high 24 confidence). This requires strengthening relevant national institutions to reduce silos and overlaps, 25 increasing knowledge exchange at the country and regional levels, and supporting engagement with 26 bilateral and multilateral funding partners. Local governments are well placed to develop policies that 27 generate social and environmental co-benefits but to do so require legal backing and adequate capacity 28 and resources. 29 Climate change mitigation is accelerated when attention is given to integrated policy and economy 30 wide approaches, and when enabling conditions (governance, institutions, behaviour and lifestyle, 31 innovation, policy, and finance), are present (robust evidence, medium agreement). Accelerating 32 climate mitigation includes simultaneously weakening high carbon systems and encouraging low 33 carbon systems; ensuring interaction between adjacent systems (e.g., energy and agriculture); 34 overcoming resistance to policies (e.g., from incumbents in high carbon emitting industries), including 35 by providing transitional support to the vulnerable and negatively affected by distributional impacts; 36 inducing changes in consumer practices and routines; providing transition support; and addressing 37 coordination challenges in policy and governance. Such policies include regulatory instruments such 6 as energy efficiency programmes or technical standards and codes, carbon pricing, financial support for 7 low-carbon energy technologies and efficiency, voluntary agreements, and regulation of land use 8 practices. 9 A..acThe vast majority of literature reviewed for this report examines the effect of particular instruments in 10 particular contexts , and only a small number directly or plausibly infer global impacts 11 of policies. Policies also differ in design, scope, and stringency, may change over time as they require 12 amendments or new laws, and often partially overlap with other instruments. These factors complicate 13 analysis, because they give rise to the potential for double counting emissions reductions that have been 14 observed. These lines of evidence on the impact of polices include: 15 A..ad• GHG Emissions – Evidence from econometric assessments of the impact of policies in 16 countries which took on Kyoto Protocol targets; decomposition analyses that identify policy-17 related, absolute reductions from historical levels in particular countries. 19 • Proximate emission drivers – trends in the factors that drive emissions including reduced rates 20 of deforestation {7.6.2}, industrial energy efficiency {Box 16.3}, buildings energy efficiency 21 {Figure 2.22}, and the policy-driven displacement of fossil fuel combustion by renewable 22 energy.     ). The Kyoto 2 Protocol led to measurable and substantial avoided emissions, including in 20 countries with Kyoto first 3 commitment period targets that have experienced a decade of declining absolute emissions. It also built 4 national capacity for GHG accounting, catalysed the creation of GHG markets, and increased 5 investments in low-carbon technologies. Other international agreements and institutions have led to 6 avoided CO2 emissions from land-use practices, as well as avoided emissions of some non-CO2 7 greenhouse gases. (medium confidence
    ) 8 A..baNew forms of international cooperation have emerged since AR5 in line with an evolving 9 understanding of effective mitigation policies, processes, and institutions. Both new and pre-10 existing forms of co-operation are vital for achieving climate mitigation goals in the context of 11 sustainable development (high confidence
    ). While previous IPCC assessments have noted important 12 synergies between the outcomes of climate mitigation and achieving sustainable development 13 objectives, there now appear to be synergies between the two processes themselves (medium 14 confidence). Since AR5, international cooperation has shifted towards facilitating national level 15 mitigation action through numerous channels, including though processes established under the 16 UNFCCC regime and through regional and sectoral agreements and organisations. 18 A..bbParticipation in international agreements and transboundary networks is associated with the 19 adoption of climate policies at the national and sub-national levels, as well as by non-state actors 20 (high confidence
    ). International cooperation helps countries achieve long-term mitigation targets when 21 it supports development and diffusion of low-carbon technologies, often at the level of individual 22 sectors, which can simultaneously lead to significant benefits in the areas of sustainable development 23 and equity (medium confidence
    ). 24 A..bcInternational cooperation under the UN climate regime took an important new direction with the 25 entry into force of the 2015 Paris Agreement, which strengthened the objective of the UN climate 26 regime, including its long-term temperature goal, while adopting a different architecture to that 27 of the Kyoto Protocol (high confidence
    ). The core national commitments under the Kyoto Protocol 28 were legally binding quantified emission targets for developed countries tied to well-defined 29 mechanisms for monitoring and enforcement. By contrast, the commitments under the Paris Agreement 30 are primarily procedural, extend to all parties, and are designed to trigger domestic policies and 31 measures, enhance transparency, and stimulate climate investments, particularly in developing 32 countries, and to lead iteratively to rising levels of ambition across all countries. Issues of equity remain 33 of central importance in the UN climate regime, notwithstanding shifts in the operationalisation of 34 ‘common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities’ from Kyoto to Paris. 35 A..bdThere are conflicting views on whether the Paris Agreement’s commitments and mechanisms will 36 lead to the attainment of its stated goals (medium confidence
    ). Arguments in support of the Paris 37 Agreement are that the processes it initiates and supports will in multiple ways lead, and indeed have 38 already led, to rising levels of ambition over time. The recent proliferation of national mid-century net 39 zero GHG targets can be attributed in part to the Paris Agreement. Moreover, its processes and 40 commitments will enhance countries’ abilities to achieve their stated level of ambition, particularly 41 among developing countries. Arguments against the Paris Agreement are that it lacks a mechanism to 42 review the adequacy of individual Parties’ nationally determined contributions (NDCs), that 43 collectively current NDCs are inconsistent in their level of ambition with achieving the Paris 44 Agreement’s long-term temperature goal, that its processes will not lead to sufficiently rising levels of 45 ambition in the NDCs, and that NDCs will not be achieved because the targets, policies and measures 46 they contain are not legally binding at the international level. To some extent, arguments on both sides 47 A..beAC CE PTEDV ERSIONA..bfSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSA..bgTS-120 Total pages: 142are aligned with different analytic frameworks, including assumptions about the main barriers to 1 mitigation that international cooperation can help overcome. The extent to which countries increase the 2 ambition of their NDCs and ensure they are effectively implemented will depend in part on the 3 successful implementation of the support mechanisms in the Paris Agreement, and in turn will 4 determine whether the goals of the Paris Agreement are met (high confidence
    ). 5 A..bhInternational cooperation outside the UNFCCC processes and agreements provides critical 6 support for mitigation in particular regions, sectors and industries, for particular types of 7 emissions, and at the sub- and trans-national levels (high confidence
    ). Agreements addressing ozone 8 depletion, transboundary air pollution, and release of mercury are all leading to reductions in the 9 emissions of specific greenhouse gases. Cooperation is occurring at multiple governance levels 10 including cities. Transnational partnerships and alliances involving non-state and sub-national actors 11 are also playing a growing role in stimulating low-carbon technology diffusion and emissions 12 reductions (medium confidence
    ). Such transnational efforts include those focused on climate litigation; 13 the impacts of these are unclear but promising. Climate change is being addressed in a growing number 14 of international agreements operating at sectoral levels, as well as within the practices of many 15 multilateral organisations and institutions. Sub-global and regional cooperation, often described as 16 climate clubs, can play an important role in accelerating mitigation, including the potential for reducing 17 mitigation costs through linking national carbon markets, although actual examples of these remain 18 limited. 19 A..biInternational cooperation will need to be strengthened in several key respects in order to support 20 mitigation action consistent with limiting temperature rise to well below 2°C in the context of 21 sustainable development and equity (high confidence
    . Many developing countries’ NDCs have 22 components or additional actions that are conditional on receiving assistance with respect to finance, 23 technology development and transfer, and capacity building, greater than what has been provided to 24 date. Sectoral and sub-global cooperation is providing critical support, and yet there is room for further 25 progress. In some cases, notably with respect to aviation and shipping, sectoral agreements have 26 adopted climate mitigation goals that fall far short of what would be required to achieve the long-term 27 temperature goal of the Paris Agreement. Moreover, there are cases where international cooperation 28 may be hindering mitigation efforts, namely evidence that trade and investment agreements, as well as 29 agreements within the energy sector, impede national mitigation efforts (medium confidence
    ). 30 International cooperation is emerging but so far fails to fully address transboundary issues associated 31 with solar radiation modification and carbon dioxide removal. 33 A..bj34 A..bkTS. 6.3 Societal aspects of mitigation 35 A..blSocial equity reinforces capacity and motivation for mitigating climate change (medium 36 confidence). Impartial governance such as fair treatment by law-and-order institutions, fair treatment 37 by gender, and income equity, increases social trust, thus enabling demand-side climate policies. High 38 status (often high carbon) item consumption may be reduced by taxing absolute wealth without 39 compromising well-being. 40 41 Policies that increase the political access and participation of women, racialised, and marginalised 42 groups, increase the democratic impetus for climate action (high confidence
    ). Fundamental inequities in access to finance as well 3 as finance terms and conditions, and countries’ exposure to physical impacts of climate change 4 overall, result in a worsening outlook for a global just transition (high confidence
    Decarbonising 5 the economy requires global action to address fundamental economic inequities and overcome the 6 climate investment trap that exists for many developing countries. For these countries the costs and 7 risks of financing often represent a significant challenge for stakeholders at all levels. This challenge is 8 exacerbated by these countries’ general economic vulnerability and indebtedness. The rising public 9 fiscal costs of mitigation, and of adapting to climate shocks, is affecting many countries and worsening 10 public indebtedness and country credit ratings at a time when there were already significant stresses on 11 public finances. The COVID-19 pandemic has made these stresses worse and tightened public finances 12 still further. Other major challenges for commercial climate finance include: the mismatch between 13 capital and investment needs, home bias23considerations, differences in risk perceptions for regions, as 14 well as limited institutional capacity to ensure safeguards are effective. (high confidence
    ) 15 A..bxInvestors, central banks, and financial regulators are driving increased awareness of climate risk. 16 This increased awareness can support climate policy development and implementation (high 17 confidence). Climate-related financial risks arise from physical impacts of climate change 18 (already relevant in the short term), and from a disorderly transition to a low carbon economy. 19 Awareness of these risks is increasing, leading also to concerns about financial stability. Financial 20 regulators and institutions have responded with multiple regulatory and voluntary initiatives to assess 21 and address these risks. Yet despite these initiatives, climate-related financial risks remain greatly 22 underestimated by financial institutions and markets, limiting the capital reallocation needed for the 23 low-carbon transition. Moreover, risks relating to national and international inequity – which act as a 24 barrier to the transformation – are not yet reflected in decisions by the financial community. Stronger 25 steering by regulators and policy makers has the potential to close this gap. Despite the increasing 26 attention of investors to climate change, there is limited evidence that this attention has directly 27 impacted emission reductions. This leaves high uncertainty, both near-term (2021-30) and longer-term 28 (2021-50), on the feasibility of an alignment of financial flows with the Paris Agreement goals (high 29 confidence). 30 A..byProgress on the alignment of financial flows with low GHG emissions pathways remains slow. 31 There is a climate financing gap which reflects a persistent misallocation of global capital (high 32 confidence) . Persistently high levels of both public and private fossil-fuel related financing 33 continue to be of major concern despite promising recent commitments. This reflects policy 34 misalignment, the current perceived risk-return profile of fossil fuel-related investments, and political 35 economy constraints (high confidence
    ). Estimates of climate finance flows24exhibit highly divergent 36 patterns across regions and sectors and a slowing growth . When the perceived risks are too high, 37 the misallocation of abundant savings persists and investors refrain from investing in infrastructure and 38 industry in search of safer financial assets, even earning low or negative real returns. (high confidence

Innovation has also led to, and exacerbated, trade-offs in relation to sustainable 3 development. Innovation can leverage action to mitigate climate change by reinforcing other 4 interventions. In conjunction with other enabling conditions innovation can support system transitions 5 to limit warming and help shift development pathways. The currently widespread implementation of 6 solar PV and LED lighting, for instance, could not have happened without technological innovation. 7 Technological innovation can also bring about new and improved ways of delivering services that are 8 essential to human well-being (high confidence
    ) . At the same time as delivering 9 benefits, innovation can result in trade-offs that undermine both progress on mitigation and progress 10 towards other sustainable development goals. Trade-offs include negative externalities – for instance 11 greater environmental pollution and social inequalities – rebound effects leading to lower net emission 12 reductions or even increases in emissions, and increased dependency on foreign knowledge and 13 providers (high confidence
    . Effective governance and policy have the potential to avoid and minimise 14 such misalignments (medium evidence, high agreement). 15 A..dfA systemic view of innovation to direct and organize the processes has grown over the last decade. 16 This systemic view of innovation takes into account the role of actors, institutions, and their 17 interactions and can inform how innovation systems that vary across technologies, sectors and 18 countries, can be strengthened (high confidence
    . Where a systemic view of 19 innovation has been taken, it has enabled the development and implementation of indicators that are 20 better able to provide insights in innovation processes. This, in turn, has enabled the analysis and 21 strengthening of innovation systems. Traditional quantitative innovation indicators mainly include 22 R&D investments and patents. Figure TS.26 illustrates that energy-related RD&D has risen slowly in 23 the last two decades, and that there has been a reorientation of the portfolio of funded energy 24 technologies. Systemic indicators of innovation, however, go well beyond these approaches. They 25 include structural innovation system elements including actors and networks, as well as indicators for 26 how innovation systems function, such as access to finance, employment in relevant sectors, and 27 lobbying activities {16.3.4, Table 16.7}. For example, in Latin America, monitoring systemic 28 innovation indicators for the effectiveness of agroecological mitigation approaches has provided 29 insights on the appropriateness and social alignment of new technologies and practices {Box 16.5}. 30 Climate-energy-economy models, including integrated assessment models, generally employ a stylised 31 and necessarily incomplete view of innovation, and have yet to incorporate a systemic representation 32 of innovation systems. 33 A..dg34 AC CE PTEDV ERSIONA..dhSUBJECT TOFINALEDITSA..diTS-128 Total pages: 142A..dj1 Figure TS.26: Fraction of public energy research, development and demonstration (RD&D (spending by 2 technology over time for IEA (largely OECD) countries between 1974 and 2018. 3 A..dk4 A..dlA systemic perspective on technological change can provide insights to policymakers supporting 5 their selection of effective innovation policy instruments (high confidence
